questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents due to difficulty keeping up with other children at daycare. Over the last 2 months, the daycare teachers have noticed that the patient cannot walk independently and seems more tired than usual. The parents have noticed that the boy finds it difficult to climb stairs. He has been eating and growing normally, and he has no past medical history except for an upper respiratory tract infection 3 weeks ago that resolved on its own. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 19/min and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows enlarged and nontender calves bilaterally. When asked to rise from the floor, the boy uses hand support to push himself to an upright position. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Serum creatinine kinase is 14,200 U/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
This young boy with progressive proximal muscle weakness, Gower sign (using hand support to push himself to an upright position) and elevated creatinine kinase is most likely suffering from Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a frameshift deletion mutation in the dystrophin gene, leading to the production of truncated or absent dystrophin protein. Affected patients present at age 2-3 years with muscle weakness that begins in pelvic girdle muscles and progresses superiorly. Serum creatinine kinase (CK) and aldolase levels are usually elevated, and genetic testing confirms the absence of dystrophin protein.

DMD should be differentiated from Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD), which usually manifests later in life (age 5-15 years), with a milder degree of clinical involvement. Patients typically remain ambulatory at least until age 16, and commonly well into adult life. Intellectual disability is less common, and there is relative preservation of neck flexor muscle strength. Cardiac involvement in BMD is often predominant and can manifest early in life. Moreover, in contrast to DMD, patients with BMD,typically have abnormal or low concentration of dystrophin protein resulting from non-frameshift mutations.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Guillain-Barré syndrome:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) can occur following a respiratory tract infection. However, GBS presents with ascending muscle weakness, hyporeflexia and neuropathic pain. Moreover, the patient's symptoms began before the respiratory tract infection, making this diagnosis unlikely.
✅ Duchenne muscular dystrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Becker muscular dystrophy:
Incorrect: Although Becker muscular dystrophy can present similar to DMD, the age of onset, however, is later in life, and the muscle weakness is less severe.
❌ Viral myositis:
Incorrect: Viral myositis can present with acute muscle pain and weakness. However, this patient’s prolonged history of proximal muscle weakness and absence of muscle tenderness makes the diagnosis unlikely.
❌ Myasthenia gravis:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis is caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptors on the postsynaptic membrane. Affected individuals most commonly present with fluctuating weakness and fatigability of ocular muscles. Moreover, it rarely affects children, and isolated proximal muscle weakness is inconsistent with the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of myoclonic epilepsy. The patient’s seizure episodes last for 30 seconds typically and are triggered by startle. Past medical history is significant for occipital infarction leading to partial loss of vision. Family history is significant for chronic intermittent muscle weakness in the patient's mother and hemiplegia in her maternal uncle. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows proximal muscle weakness. Skeletal muscle biopsy of the patient shows ragged muscle fibers. Further evaluation confirms the presence of the same inherited disease in all the affected family members. Which of the following pedigrees best describes the mode of inheritance of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with myoclonic epilepsy, a positive maternal family history of myopathies, and muscle biopsy findings demonstrating ragged muscle fibers has a presentation consistent with mitochondrial myopathy.

Mitochondrial myopathy is a rare genetic disorder that occurs when there are mutated mitochondria in muscle cells, especially skeletal muscle cells. The abnormal fibers have irregular size and shape on the cross-section, and thus the condition is known as “ragged fiber disease.” Mitochondria are cellular organelles that have their own mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), and offspring inherit the mitochondria from the mother with no paternal contribution (maternal inheritance). All offspring of affected females may show signs of disease, whereas transmission never occurs through males.

Each cell in the human body has hundreds of mitochondria, and the defects can occur in any number of mitochondria within a cell. This feature results in the presence of both normal and mutated mtDNA, resulting in variable expression in mitochondrial-inherited diseases. This phenomenon is called heteroplasmy, and it can be seen in this patient’s family: the mother has mild symptoms of myopathy, the maternal uncle has more severe symptoms with hemiplegia, and the patient has severe symptoms manifesting with epilepsy.  

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ :
Incorrect: This pedigree represents autosomal dominant inheritance, which can affect 50% of the children of one affected parent. Moreover, both male and females can have the disease and can pass it on to their children; mitochondrial disorders, in contrast, can only be passed on by the mother.
❌ :
Incorrect: This pedigree represents X-linked dominant inheritance, wherein the affected father transmits the disease to all daughters and none of his sons, while the affected mother can transmit to 50% of daughters and sons (e.g., fragile X syndrome and hypophosphatemic rickets)
❌ :
Incorrect: This pedigree represents X-linked recessive transmission. Male offspring of carrier mothers have a 50% chance of being affected, whereas the female offspring have a 50% chance of being carriers. There is no male-to-male transmission, and the disease can often skip generations.
❌ :
Incorrect: This pedigree represents autosomal recessive transmission. With 2 carrier (heterozygous) parents, 25% of children will be affected (homozygous), 50% of children will be carriers, and 25% of children will be neither affected nor carriers. Autosomal recessive conditions tend to skip generations.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of exercise intolerance. His symptoms have been ongoing for many years but have recently become more bothersome after he started playing soccer for his high school team. He fatigues more easily than his friends and cannot keep up with them during matches. The patient also experiences frequent bruising after minor falls. Family history is noncontributory. In the office, his temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 108/73 mmHg, pulse is 65/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Physical examination reveals hyperelastic skin, hypermobile joints and multiple bruises over the bilateral lower extremities. Examination of the chest reveals the following finding:  


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely underlying etiology of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Reduced levels of clotting factor VIII
Reversed positioning of major visceral organs
Reduced synthesis of type I collagen

questions.solution:
This patient has pectus excavatum, hyperelastic skin, and a history of increased bruising tendency. He most likely has underlying Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is often caused by a mutation in type V collagen.

Pectus excavatum (also termed funnel chest) occurs when the sternal cartilage grows abnormally, leading to a caved-in or sunken appearance of the anterior thoracic wall. The condition can compress the cardiac cavities and cause symptoms including exercise intolerance, poor endurance, shortness of breath, and chest pain. Pectus excavatum can be associated with conditions such as Marfan syndrome, mitral valve prolapse, osteogenesis imperfecta, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

An additional sternal abnormality is pectus carinatum (also termed pigeon chest) and is characterized by the sternum protruding outward. This condition is typically asymptomatic; however, there can be tenderness at the protrusion site, and individuals may experience tachypnea during intense exercise. Pectus carinatum can be associated with scoliosis, Marfan syndrome, Noonan syndrome, and osteogenesis imperfecta.  




Option Analysis

❌ Congenital defect in fibrillin glycoprotein  :
Incorrect: Marfan syndrome is caused by a congenital defect in fibrillin. The condition can cause pectus excavatum, hyperelastic skin, and hypermobile joints. However, Marfan syndrome does not typically cause an increased bruising tendency. Moreover, Marfan syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, whereas this patient’s family history is noncontributory.  
❌ Reduced levels of clotting factor VIII  :
Incorrect: Hemophilia A is caused by a deficiency in factor VIII, which predisposes patients to bleeding. However, hemophilia A would not account for the patient’s hypermobile joints or pectus excavatum.  
❌ Reversed positioning of major visceral organs  :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes situs inversus. However, situs inversus would not cause the sunk-in chest wall seen in this patient.  
✅ Mutation in type V collagen  :
Correct: See main explanation.  
❌ Reduced synthesis of type I collagen  :
Incorrect: Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by reduced production of type I collagen and can manifest with pectus excavatum. Individuals will also have blue sclera, teeth abnormalities, hearing loss, and a history of multiple fractures. These symptoms are not present in this patient.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant boy is evaluated for the first time since delivery. The patient was born at 40 weeks gestation via vaginal delivery and had a normal prenatal and postnatal birth history. He feeds 2-3 oz of breastmilk and formula every 2-3 hours. He is in the 75<sup>th</sup> percentile for height, 75<sup>th</sup> percentile for weight, and 50<sup>th</sup> percentile for head circumference. On physical examination, there is prominent head posturing. The head is tilted to the right side, and the chin is rotated to the left shoulder. A mass is palpable in the inferior portion of the neck on the right side. The mass is firm and does not transilluminate with a penlight. The rest of the physical examination, including the reflexes and muscular tone of the extremities, is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Torticollis results from a contraction or shortening of the neck muscles, such as the sternocleidomastoid or trapezius muscle. This condition typically presents with the head tilted towards the affected side and the chin rotated away from the affected side, limiting the neck’s range of motion. This posturing is because the condition mimics the action of the sternocleidomastoid, which functions to flex the head toward the side of contraction (in this case, the right) and laterally rotate the head or chin away from the side of the contraction (in this case, the left).  

Torticollis can be congenital or acquired, as described below: 
  •  Congenital torticollis is the most common type of torticollis. This postural deformity of the neck develops prenatally and is most often caused by the development of a fibrous tissue tumor in the sternocleidomastoid muscle and less often by neurological or bony abnormalities.  
  •  There is also congenital muscular torticollis, a postural deformity that is typically evident 2-4 weeks after delivery and often occurs during delivery when there is tearing of the muscle fibers of the baby's neck, resulting in subsequent fibrosis and shortening of the neck muscles.   
  •  Acquired torticollis typically appears after delivery and can be caused by various conditions that cause injury or inflammation to the muscles of the neck. These can range from trauma to infection or neurological disorders. Acquired torticollis typically occurs in children but can occur in adults as well.  
Adults usually acquire a type of torticollis referred to as spasmodic torticollis, or cervical dystonia, resulting from strenuous movement or awkward positioning for too long. Spasmodic torticollis is a chronic and painful condition characterized by involuntary contraction of the neck muscles, leading to involuntary tilting, turning, flexing, or extending the neck. In most cases, the cause of spasmodic torticollis is unknown, but more serious causes include cervical spine injuries, such as fractures and subluxations.  



Option Analysis

❌ Clavicle fracture:
Incorrect: Clinical findings of a clavicle fracture include asymmetric contour, crepitus, edema, decreased or absent movement of the arm on the affected side, and crying with passive movement of the arm on the affected side. This infant more likely has a diagnosis of congenital muscular torticollis.  
❌ Vertebral anomaly:
Incorrect: Although a radiograph was not performed on this patient, the clinical symptoms suggest congenital muscular torticollis, not a vertebral anomaly.  
❌ Central nervous system lesion:
Incorrect: Central nervous system (CNS) lesions may also cause a head tilt in young infants. However, infants with CNS lesions usually have abnormal neurologic findings (e.g., cranial nerve palsy, recurrent vomiting). This infant more likely has a diagnosis of congenital muscular torticollis.  
❌ Lymphangioma:
Incorrect: Lymphangioma (previously known as a cystic hygroma) is another cause of a neck mass in a young infant. In contrast to this sternocleidomastoid mass of congenital muscular torticollis, which is firm and does not transilluminate, cystic hygromas are soft and do transilluminate.  
✅ Congenital muscular torticollis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother to be evaluated for elbow pain. He was forcefully pulled onto the curb by his mother after inadvertently stepping into the street. The patient has refused to move his right arm since the incident. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an irritable child holding his right upper limb with his left hand. The affected elbow is flexed and the forearm pronated. There is no visible erythema, swelling, or deformity. There is limited range of motion on physical examination. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Radial head subluxation (i.e. nursemaid’s elbow) is a common injury in young children (1-4 years of age). It is the most common upper extremity injury in infants and young children presenting to the emergency department. It is typically caused by axial traction on an outstretched, pronated forearm. With sudden traction on the distal radius, the annular ligament slips over the head of the radius at the level of the radiohumeral joint, where it becomes entrapped.    

Children with radial head subluxationIt typically present holding the injured arm in a flexed and pronated position and refusing to move it. Patients present with sudden, acute pain of the affected arm. Notably, pain does not always localize to the elbow and there is typically no swelling, bruising, or deformity of the arm. The diagnosis is clinical and most patients can be managed with closed manual reduction by either hyperpronation of the forearm (preferred) or supination of the forearm with flexion of the elbow.  

Option Analysis

❌ Biceps tendon:
Incorrect: Biceps tendon rupture typically occurs in older adults secondary to forceful extension of the elbow on a fully contracted biceps muscle. Patients may hear or feel a “popping” sensation.There is often a visible ‘Popeye deformity' in the mid-upper arm reflective of the shortened biceps brachii. Limited range of motion at the elbow joint as seen in this patient would not be expected.  
✅ Annular ligament:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral epicondyle tendon:
Incorrect: Lateral epicondyle tendonitis can cause pain and tenderness at the lateral elbow. However with this condition there is full range of motion of the elbow joint.  
❌ Medial epicondyle tendon:
Incorrect: Medial epicondyle tendonitis can cause pain and tenderness at the medial epicondyle. However with this condition there is full  range of motion of the elbow joint.  
❌ Interosseous membrane of the forearm:
Incorrect: The interosseous membrane of the forearm is a connective tissue that lies between the radius and ulna. It is usually affected in patients with a radius or ulna fractures following a fall on an outstretched hand.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of low back pain. The patient is participating in gymnastics training and has had difficulty preparing for an upcoming competition due to persistent low back pain that is worse with movement and relieved with rest. The patient is otherwise healthy. He has not had any recent injury or trauma. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the low back is noted to be hyperlordotic. Pain is elicited with passive extension of the back. The straight leg test is negative bilaterally. A radiograph of the lumbar spine is shown below. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Repetitive stress on the pars interarticularis

questions.solution:
This adolescent patient presents for evaluation of low back. Imaging reveals grade 1 L4 on L5 spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis refers to anterior displacement of the vertebral body with respect to the adjacent vertebral bodies. Spondylolisthesis can be caused by degenerative changes in the spine in adult patients. It can also be congenital and seen in children. In both adolescents and children, pars defects can be caused by overuse of the low back, mainly from sports that involve repetitive back bend-like motion. This can lead to fracture of the pars interarticularis (spondylolysis) which may progress to anterior subluxation of one vertebral body with respect to an adjacent vertebral body (spondylolisthesis).  

Lumbar spondylolisthesis can present with intermittent localized low back pain. The pain is typically worsened with  flexing and extending at the affected segment of the vertebrae. There may be pain with direct palpation on physical examination. Patients can also have radicular pain if the exiting nerve roots become compressed.  

Radiography is the initial test for diagnosing spondylolisthesis. CT of the spine has the highest sensitivity and specificity for diagnosis and may be performed after spinal radiographs are completed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Repetitive stress on the pars interarticularis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Compression of L4 nerve root:
Incorrect: Lumbar radiculopathy most commonly results from bulging intervertebral discs. The symptoms often include low back pain with associated radiation down the lower extremities. A straight leg raise is often positive with this condition. This patient’s signs and symptoms are not consistent with lumbar radiculopathy.  
❌ Lytic bone lesions:
Incorrect: The above lumbar film does not demonstrate lytic bony lesions, which often appear as punched-out areas of bone.  
❌ Lumbar erector spinae weakness:
Incorrect: Weakness of the lumbar erector spinae can lead to low back pain.  However this would not increase the risk of spondylolisthesis seen in this patient’s radiograph.  
❌ Narrowing of the intraspinal canal:
Incorrect: Spinal stenosis is an uncommon condition in adolescent patients. It most commonly presents in elderly patients with pain that is worsened with walking or activity and is relieved by sitting, lying down, or bending forward at the waist.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of right arm pain following a fall out of a tree. The patient’s parent states he was in his treehouse when he fell from the balcony directly onto an outstretched right arm. Vitals are within normal limits. Examination reveals a young male in acute distress who is holding his right arm against his body. There is tenderness and swelling of the right mid-forearm without visible deformity. A radiograph of the right forearm is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
A greenstick fracture is a partial thickness fracture in which the cortex and periosteum are disrupted on one side of the bone but remain unfractured on the opposite side. They commonly occur in long bones (e.g., fibula, tibia, ulna, radius, humerus) and most commonly occur in the radius, ulna, or humerus following a fall on an outstretched arm.

Prior to ossification, the majority of pediatric bone is compliant, calcified cartilage. Due to this increased compliance, pediatric bones will bow and bend under stress instead of fracture as in adult bone. This unique property of pediatric bone results in several distinctive fracture patterns:  

  •  Greenstick: partial-thickness fracture where cortex and periosteum are only interrupted on one side of the bone, while they remain uninterrupted on the opposite side 
  •  Torus: incomplete fractures of the shaft of a long bone characterized by bulging of the cortex 
  •  Spiral injuries: bending injuries rather than full-thickness cortical breaks
 

Greenstick fracture, Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Option Analysis

✅ Greenstick fracture of the radius   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Buckle fracture of the radius   :
Incorrect: Torus fractures, also known as buckle fractures, are incomplete fractures of the shaft of a long bone characterized by bulging of the cortex (as indicated by the yellow arrow). This patient has evidence of a cortical breach on one side of the bone, indicating a different diagnosis.
 
 
Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  
❌ Dietary vitamin D deficiency   :
Incorrect: Dietary vitamin D deficiency can lead to impaired bone mineralization, bowing of the long bones, and widening of the growth plate. These findings are not seen on this child’s x-ray.   
❌ Primary bone malignancy   :
Incorrect: Osteosarcomas are the most common primary bone malignancy in children. The tumor typically presents with localized bony pain and a palpable soft tissue mass. Characteristic findings on X-ray include a sunburst pattern and periosteal reaction.   
❌ Radial head subluxation   :
Incorrect: Radial head subluxation occurs when children are lifted or pulled by their wrist or arm causing the radial head to slip under the annular ligament. Radiographs of the affected arm are typically normal.

questions.text: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the office for a routine newborn evaluation. She was born at 40 weeks gestation to a 28-year-old primigravid mother via cesarean section due to breech presentation. The remainder of the pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated, and all prenatal tests were within normal limits. The infant breastfeeds every 4-5 hours and sleeps 7-8 hours at night. Physical examination shows an alert female infant with normal strength and movement in all extremities. There are four skin creases along the patient’s inner right thigh and two on the left thigh. Further examination reveals a limb length discrepancy of 1 inch. The physician gently adducts and applies pressure to the right hip which results in posterior displacement and a palpable clunk. Which of the following best describes the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Dysgenesis of the acetabulum and femoral head
Avascular necrosis of the femoral head
Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck
Traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle

questions.solution:
Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) occurs when the acetabulum is shallow or poorly formed, resulting in subluxation or dislocation of the femoral head. DDH occurs more commonly in newborn females than in males; other risk factors include firstborns, breech presentation, as well as family history of DDH.   DDH is commonly asymptomatic; however, the physical examination may demonstrate the following findings:
 
  •  Positive Barlow maneuver: To perform this maneuver on a supine neonate, the physician adducts the hips and applies downward pressure to dislocate the hip posteriorly. If positive, the physician can feel a clunk or jerk with hip dislocation.  
  •  Positive Ortolani maneuver: This maneuver attempts to reduce a dislocated hip, as would occur with a positive Barlow maneuver. To perform this maneuver, the physician abducts the hip and applies upward pressure (opposite that of the Barlow maneuver); if positive, the hip can be felt relocating into the acetabulum. 
  •  The Galeazzi sign assesses for femoral asymmetry. If the hip is dislocated, the affected femur (and therefore knee) will appear shorter compared with the normal limb (limb-length discrepancy).  
  •  Asymmetry in the position and/or the number of the gluteal or thigh skin folds may be a clue for DDH (with more gluteal folds suggestive of DDH).  
Infants <4 months of age with an abnormal examination should have further evaluation via ultrasound. After age 4 months, the femoral head and acetabulum ossify, and therefore, x-rays become the preferred modality for evaluation. Confirmed DDH is treated with a Pavlik harness–a splint that holds the hip in proper alignment to allow for appropriate bony maturation. 

Option Analysis

✅ Dysgenesis of the acetabulum and femoral head   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Avascular necrosis of the femoral head   :
Incorrect: Legg-Calvé-Perthes refers to idiopathic avascular necrosis of the femoral head that is often seen in children between the ages of 4 and 8 years of age. Children typically present with a painful limp as well as decreased internal rotation and abduction of the hip. This neonate demonstrates a positive Barlow maneuver (inducible dislocation of the hip), suggesting a different condition.   
❌ Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck   :
Incorrect: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) refers to slipping of the femoral head from the femoral neck. The typical presentation involves an adolescent male with obesity who presents with a painful limp as well as pain in the groin, hip, or knee.   
❌ Traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle   :
Incorrect: Osgood-Schlatter disease is an inflammatory condition of the tibial tuberosity secondary to overuse injury. The typical patient is a child between the ages of 12-17 who participates in sports involving repetitive jumping.   
❌ Normal development   :
Incorrect: This neonate is presenting with asymmetric thigh and buttock folds, along with a positive Barlow maneuver (inducible dislocation of the hip). These findings are not normal findings in a newborn.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician for evaluation of an abnormal gait. The patient first noticed a dull pain in his left medial thigh and knee three weeks ago and reports it has been difficult to bear weight on the left leg over the past week. He has no history of trauma to the leg or hip. He had an upper respiratory tract infection one month ago. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 116/72 mm Hg. The patient is at the 50th percentile for height and 95th percentile for weight. Physical examination demonstrates an antalgic gait. The physician reproduces the pain with flexion, external rotation, and abduction of the left hip. A left hip radiograph with a frog-leg lateral view is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This young male with a history of obesity presents with a several week history of a worsening, painful limp and knee and thigh pain. The X-ray of the left hip demonstrates a slipped epiphysis, confirming the diagnosis of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

SCFE occurs when the femoral epiphysis is displaced posteriorly and inferiorly relative to the femoral head and neck. The exact mechanism and pathophysiology of this condition remain unclear; however, it is likely induced by conditions that place an increased axial load across a relatively weak physis. This condition is commonly observed in adolescents with obesity, but it can also be seen in patients with underlying endocrinopathies (e.g. hypothyroidism).

The pain associated with SCFE is most often reported in the hip; however, it may also be present in the groin, thigh, or knee. On average, patients endorse 4-5 months of symptoms prior to diagnosis. On physical examination, the patient may have a limited internal rotation of the hip, and they often externally rotate the leg at rest to alleviate pain.

Anteroposterior and frog-leg lateral radiographs of the pelvis confirm the slipped epiphysis, which characteristically appears as displaced “scooped ice cream.” Treatment involves surgical pinning of the epiphysis to prevent additional slippage. If not treated, avascular necrosis and collapse or deformity of the femoral head may result.  

Option Analysis

✅ Slipped capital femoral epiphysis   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Transient synovitis   :
Incorrect: Transient synovitis, also known as toxic synovitis, is a self-limited inflammatory condition of the hip that occurs following an upper respiratory infection or diarrheal illness. While this patient has a history of a recent upper respiratory tract infection, the X-ray findings suggest a different diagnosis.   
❌ Legg-Calvé-Perthes   :
Incorrect: Legg-Calvé-Perthes (LCP) disease refers to idiopathic avascular necrosis of the femoral head that presents most commonly in males ages 3-12. Patients typically present with insidious-onset hip pain and an antalgic gait. X-ray findings typically reveal a “crescent sign” as opposed to this patient’s “scooped ice cream” sign.   
❌ Developmental dysplasia of the hip   :
Incorrect: Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) is a condition commonly seen in neonates. Clinical clues include asymmetric gluteal/thigh creases, apparent limb-length discrepancy, as well as positive Barlow and Ortolani maneuvers. This patient’s chronic, painful hip joint, age, and X-ray findings suggest a different diagnosis.   
❌ Septic arthritis   :
Incorrect: Septic arthritis is a surgical emergency which involves infectious arthritis of the joint space. This patient’s presentation, including the chronic nature of his pain and paucity of systemic findings (e.g. fever), suggests a different diagnosis.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for acute onset left elbow pain. She was playing in her sandbox when her parent pulled her by the arm to take her inside. Vitals are within normal limits. Examination reveals a young girl who keeps her hand in a pronated and extended position. Any manipulation of the arm causes the girl to cry. There is no swelling or deformity. The physician hyperpronates the forearm, resulting in a click with immediate cessation of pain and resumption of the patient using her arm. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This young girl presents with classic history and presentation of radial head subluxation (or “nursemaid’s elbow”), which refers to subluxation of the radial head from the annular ligament. The usual mechanism of injury is an upward force on the arm, such as pulling a toddler upward by the hand or wrist. The radial head in children younger than 6 years has a more cylindrical shape, allowing it to slip more easily from the annular ligament which normally holds the bone in place.

The affected arm is often held in extension and pronation, and the child may refuse to move the arm secondary to pain. Tenderness is typically present at the radial head, and the patient will resist forearm pronation, supination, flexion, and extension. Without a concomitant injury, ecchymosis, erythema, edema, or signs of trauma will be absent. The diagnosis is clinical, and imaging is not required unless additional injuries are suspected. A plain radiograph of the affected arm will be normal.

Treatment of radial head subluxation involves closed reduction via hyper-pronation or supination/flexion at the elbow. A successful reduction results in immediate cessation of pain, and most children will use their arm again within minutes.  

Option Analysis

✅ Radial head subluxation   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Incomplete fracture   :
Incorrect: Incomplete fractures (Greenstick fractures) are fractures that extend only partway through the width of bone following an angular or bending force. Greenstick fractures result in point tenderness at the site of the fracture with evidence of overlying swelling. A fracture would not spontaneously resolve, making this diagnosis less likely.   
❌ Brachial plexus injury   :
Incorrect: Brachial plexus injuries typically result from birth trauma due to excessive traction on the neonate’s head, neck, or arm. These injuries may also occur secondary to excess traction on the arm (e.g. from a fall). Neurological injury, however, would not spontaneously resolve, making this diagnosis less likely.   
❌ Complete fracture   :
Incorrect: Complete fractures of the arm are common in children. Clinical presentation includes an obvious deformity of the arm, along with localized ecchymosis, swelling, and pain. However, a fracture would not spontaneously resolve, making this diagnosis less likely.   
❌ Tendinitis:
Incorrect: Tendonitis can affect the upper extremities but is much more common in patients with a history of chronic overuse (e.g., athletes, construction workers). This patient’s history and presentation are more consistent with radial head subluxation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes to her pediatrician’s office for evaluation of left knee pain. The pain has been present for the past 3-4 months, and worsens with running, prolonged sitting, or when going up or down steps. The patient also mentions episodes of her left knee “buckling.” She has taken ibuprofen which occasionally alleviates the pain. Vitals are within normal limits. BMI is 19.5 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination shows a normal gait. There is no visible knee deformity. When the patient is asked to perform squats, there is significant pain in the left knee. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Chronic avulsion of the secondary ossification center of the tibial tuberosity
Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck
Abnormal formation of the acetabulum and the femoral head
Muscular imbalance and decreased stability of the patellofemoral joint
Infectious arthritis of the joint space

questions.solution:
This adolescent girl presents with poorly localized anterior knee pain and clinical features suggestive of patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS). The pathogenesis of this condition is poorly understood but is likely due to anatomical variants that increase chronic contact pressure between the patella and the femur, resulting in knee pain. In addition, muscular imbalance(s) between the quadriceps and hamstrings decrease the stability of the patellofemoral joint with normal weight-bearing activities. This condition is primarily related to overuse but can also occur acutely following trauma.

Clinical features of PFPS include anterior knee pain directly under or around the patella. The pain is often worsened with activity or with walking up and down stairs. It is relieved with rest, although pain may be noted after prolonged periods of knee flexion (e.g. sitting in a chair). Diagnosis of PFPS is primarily based on patient history and examination findings. The pain is often provoked by maneuvers that involve contraction of the quadriceps with the knee in flexion (e.g. squatting). PFPS is most common in adolescent females.

Nonoperative medical management and physical therapy is the most common initial treatment course. Therapy focuses on stretching and strengthening of the quadriceps muscle.  

Option Analysis

❌ Chronic avulsion of the secondary ossification center of the tibial tuberosity   :
Incorrect: Osgood-Schlatter disease (OSD) refers to a traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle due to repetitive strain and chronic avulsion of the secondary ossification center at the tibial tuberosity. In contrast to this patient, physical examination in patients with OSD typically reveals tenderness and soft tissue or bony prominence over the tibial tubercle.   
❌ Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck   :
Incorrect: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) results from slipping of the femoral head from the femoral neck. The typical patient is an adolescent male with obesity with a painful limp as well as pain in the groin, hip, or knee. This patient has a normal gait.   
❌ Abnormal formation of the acetabulum and the femoral head   :
Incorrect: Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) results from the improper formation of the acetabulum and femoral head; the condition occurs in neonates. This adolescent patient has a different diagnosis.   
✅ Muscular imbalance and decreased stability of the patellofemoral joint   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Infectious arthritis of the joint space   :
Incorrect: Septic arthritis is a surgical emergency which involves infectious arthritis of the joint space. This patient’s presentation, including the chronic nature of her pain and paucity of systemic findings (e.g. fever), suggests a different diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy is brought to his primary pediatrician for evaluation of left knee pain. He plays basketball for his high school team, and the pain started four weeks following the start of the season. The pain is worsened with running and jumping and relieved with rest. He has no significant past medical history. Vitals are within normal limits. He is at the 75th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. Physical examination reveals anterior knee pain located at the position of the arrow, as seen in the image below. Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s condition?
 

Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Chronic avulsion of the secondary ossification center of the tibial tuberosity
Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck
Abnormal formation of the acetabulum and the femoral head
Muscular imbalance and decreased stability of the patellofemoral joint
Degenerative alterations to the patellar tendon

questions.solution:
This patient presents with swelling and tenderness over the tibial tuberosity, which is consistent with the traction apophysitis Osgood-Schlatter disease (OSD). OSD is an overuse injury characterized by inflammation and microfracture of the tibial tuberosity. Repetitive strain from repetitive jumping and strong contraction of quadriceps results in chronic avulsion at the tibial tuberosity with subsequent secondary ossification and chronic pain.

OSD typically occurs in adolescent (ages 13-14) males or females who have recently undergone a rapid growth spurt. The most common presenting complaint is gradually worsening anterior knee pain that is exacerbated with physical activity (running, jumping) and relieved with rest. Physical examination typically reveals tenderness and soft tissue or bony prominence over the tibial tubercle, as indicated by the yellow arrow in the image. In contrast, pain that is more superior and just inferior to the patella would suggest patellar tendinopathy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic avulsion of the secondary ossification center of the tibial tuberosity   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck   :
Incorrect: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) results from slipping of the femoral head from the femoral neck. The typical patient is an adolescent male with obesity who presents with a painful limp as well as pain in the groin, hip, or knee.   
❌ Abnormal formation of the acetabulum and the femoral head   :
Incorrect: Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) results from the improper formation of the acetabulum and femoral head and occurs in neonates. This patient, who presents with pain at the tibial tuberosity, has a different diagnosis.   
❌ Muscular imbalance and decreased stability of the patellofemoral joint   :
Incorrect: Patellofemoral syndrome results from malalignment of the patella (often caused by muscular imbalance). This condition results in pain around the patella or directly below the patella.   
❌ Degenerative alterations to the patellar tendon   :
Incorrect: Patellar tendinitis is an overuse injury due to repetitive jumping. Patients with this condition present with anterior knee pain that is worsened with activity. Patellar tendinitis typically results in point tenderness at the inferior pole of the patella–not over the tibial tuberosity.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician’s office for evaluation of left hip pain. The patient’s parent noticed a left-sided limp several weeks ago and initially attributed it to a fall at the playground. The pain has persisted and is minimally relieved with rest or ibuprofen. The patient has no significant past medical history. He takes no daily medications, and immunizations are up to date. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 116/72 mm Hg. The child is in the 50th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. Examination shows a well-appearing and cooperative child. With internal rotation and abduction of the left hip, range of motion is limited secondary to pain. The remainder of the examination is noncontributory. An X-ray of the patient's hip is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 
 
Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
Legg-Calvé-Perthes (LCP) disease refers to idiopathic avascular necrosis of the femoral head. The onset of LCP disease usually occurs in children between the ages of 3 and 12 years of age and preferentially affects males.

Patients typically present with gradual, chronically worsening hip pain and/or limp that is aggravated by physical activity. As the disease progresses, the physical examination may reveal limited internal rotation and abduction of the hip. Diagnosis of LCP requires a high index of suspicion as initial radiographs are often normal. Radiographs in the later course of the disease may demonstrate increased density of the femoral head or a crescentic subchondral fracture in the femoral head termed the “crescent sign.” Treatment involves physical therapy and restriction of physical activity. Surgery may be required if conservative management fails.

Option Analysis

✅ Legg-Calvé-Perthes   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Slipped capital femoral epiphysis   :
Incorrect: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis occurs when the femoral epiphysis is displaced posteriorly and inferiorly relative to the femoral head and neck. This condition most commonly occurs in adolescents with obesity.   
❌ Developmental dysplasia of the hip   :
Incorrect: Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) presents in the first few months of life. Clinical clues include asymmetric gluteal/thigh creases, apparent limb-length discrepancy, as well as positive Barlow or Ortolani maneuvers. This patient’s age, chronic limp, and X-ray findings suggest a different diagnosis.   
❌ Septic arthritis   :
Incorrect: Septic arthritis is a surgical emergency that involves infectious arthritis of the joint space. This patient’s presentation, including the chronic nature of his pain and paucity of systemic findings (e.g. fever), suggests a different diagnosis.   
❌ Transient synovitis   :
Incorrect: Transient synovitis, also known as toxic synovitis, is a self-limited inflammatory condition of the hip that occurs following an upper respiratory infection or diarrheal illness. This patient’s x-ray findings suggest a different diagnosis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by EMTs and police after a motor vehicle collision. The patient entered a highway and was struck by another vehicle at high speed. She was unrestrained and was ejected from her car. She arrives in the ED alert and oriented x3 and endorses severe pain in her neck and right axilla. Temperature is 97 F° (36.1 C°), pulse is 160/min, and blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg. On physical examination, the right arm is internally rotated and abducted and flexed at the wrist with an extended forearm. The muscular tone of the right biceps, infraspinatus, and deltoid appears diminished. She has sensory loss along the lateral surface of the right arm, up to the thumb. Imaging of the cervical vertebrae does not reveal fractures, bleeding, or evidence of impingement. X-ray of the right upper extremity does not demonstrate dislocations or fractures. Which of the following best describes the anatomic localization of this patient’s lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient suffered from a motor vehicle accident resulting in right arm weakness and numbness. While this vignette does not describe an exact mechanism of injury for this patient, it does provide physical exam findings of a flexed wrist, extended forearm, and internally rotated arm, consistent with a waiter’s tip finding. Additionally, she has evidence of sensory loss over the lateral arm up to the thumb, suggesting a brachial plexus injury at the level of the cervical nerve roots. Collectively, these examination findings are referred to as Erb palsy.

Erb palsy occurs secondary to traumatic lateral flexion of the neck, usually during trauma or childbirth. Forced lateral flexion to the brachial plexus at levels C5-C6 results in sensory loss to the lateral arm and thumb and paralysis and atrophy of the deltoid, biceps, and brachialis muscles. Treatment involves immobilization with an abduction brace and surgery.

Other brachial plexus injuries include axillary nerve injury, which can occur due to anterior shoulder dislocation or fracture at the surgical neck of the humerus. Patients with this deficit will exhibit weakness of the deltoid and impaired arm abduction and external rotation. Sensory deficits secondary to axillary nerve injuries result in numbness over the lateral shoulder. 

Option Analysis

✅ C5-C6 nerve roots  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Radial nerve  :
Incorrect: Radial nerve injury usually occurs with midshaft fractures of the humerus or with prolonged crutch use.  
❌ Ulnar nerve  :
Incorrect: Ulnar nerve injuries are usually caused by fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus or by a hook of hamate fracture.  
❌ Anterior shoulder:
Incorrect: While common and often a cause of axillary nerve injury, an anterior dislocation would be evident on x-ray.  
❌ Carpal tunnel  :
Incorrect: Neither the patient’s disease etiology nor symptomatology are congruent with findings of carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate right wrist pain. The patient was playing pick-up basketball when he tripped, fell, and landed on an outstretched right hand. He states, “I thought I might have a wrist sprain, but my fourth and fifth fingers started feeling numb, so I came to the ED to get checked out.” He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medication. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation and swelling over the hypothenar eminence. The patient’s initial right hand and wrist radiographs are unremarkable. A carpal tunnel view of the right hand is subsequently obtained and shown below. Which of the following anatomic structures is at most significant risk of injury based on this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents after a fall on an outstretched hand. He has pain over the ulnar aspect of the wrist and numbness of the fourth and fifth digits. The carpal tunnel view demonstrates a fracture to the hook of the hamate, which carries a risk of compression injury to the ulnar nerve as it passes through the Gunyon canal.

Hook of the hamate injuries are uncommon but typically occur due to a mechanism of injury involving a fall on an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury). Clinically, patients will experience pain and swelling over the ulnar aspect of the wrist and hypothenar eminence with associated ulnar nerve deficits if compression is present. Careful physical examination should be performed to assess ulnar nerve and artery function to ensure that neither is injured. This evaluation can be accomplished via 1) strength and sensation testing of the fourth and fifth digits and 2) pressing down on the radial artery and assessing if sufficient blood can reach the hand via the ulnar artery.

Hook of the hamate fractures are often missed on initial evaluation and misdiagnosed as wrist sprains, as frontal and lateral radiographs are often unremarkable.  A carpal tunnel view of the wrist can be obtained for further evaluation if suspicion remains despite normal radiographs.

Option Analysis

✅ Ulnar nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Extensor digitorum  :
Incorrect: The extensor digitorum is located on the dorsal aspect of the hand. Injury to this structure can occur when a direct force is applied to a digit held in extension. In contrast, this patient sustained a fall onto an outstretched hand and has imaging that reveals a hook of the hamate fracture.  
❌ Median nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the median nerve is unlikely to occur from the hook of the hamate fractures.  
❌ Radial nerve  :
Incorrect: Radial nerve injury does not typically occur with the hook of the hamate fractures. Instead, it more commonly occurs with humeral shaft fractures.  
❌ Radial artery  :
Incorrect: Radial artery injury does not typically occur in the setting of the hook of the hamate fractures.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician to evaluate left-sided shoulder pain and weakness for two weeks. The patient had a recent axillary lymph node dissection for breast cancer surveillance. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has normal sensation in the upper extremities on physical exam with 5/5 strength bilaterally. When asked to cross her arms, a notable physical examination finding is demonstrated in the image below. Which of the following anatomic structures is responsible for this patient’s symptoms?  


Image credit: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with shoulder pain and weakness following an axillary lymph node dissection is highly suggestive of injury to the long thoracic nerve. The long thoracic nerve arises from the anterior rami of C5, C6, and C7 and directly innervates the serratus anterior muscle. The serratus anterior muscle functions primarily to protract the scapula (a motion used by boxers when throwing a punch, which is why the serratus anterior is also known as the boxer’s muscle). Without the ability to protract the scapula, the affected scapula protrudes, resulting in a “winged scapula.”

Other surgical procedures that damage the long thoracic nerve include radical mastectomy, thoracic sympathectomy, transaxillary thoracotomy, misplaced intercostal drains, and video-assisted thoracotomy  (VAT) port insertion. Management of long thoracic nerve injury includes physiotherapy and surgery.  

Option Analysis

✅ Serratus anterior  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Brachial plexus  :
Incorrect: Injuries to the brachial plexus often occur due to hyperabduction of the arm or neck as a result of trauma or childbirth. The long thoracic nerve is typically unaffected by these injuries.  
❌ Trapezius  :
Incorrect: The trapezius elevates the shoulders. This patient has evidence of a winged scapula–likely due to a laceration of the long thoracic nerve and subsequent dysfunction of the serratus anterior.  
❌ Radial nerve  :
Incorrect: Radial nerve compression, or “Saturday night palsy,” results in decreased sensation on the dorsoradial aspect of the hand and wrist, along with wrist drop on physical examination.  
❌ C7 nerve root  :
Incorrect: An isolated injury to the C7 nerve root is rare and low-yield for examination purposes. On rare occasions, injury to the C7 nerve root is associated with Erb palsy.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being found down outside a bar. Emergency medical services were called to the scene after several bystanders saw the person lying in the street. The patient is poorly responsive and unable to provide a history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. The patient’s speech is slurred, and he responds only to pain. Physical examination reveals scattered abrasions over the arms and legs and a 1 cm laceration over the right occiput. The patient is further noted to have swelling of the right hand. A radiograph of the right hand is obtained and shown below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of injury associated with this injury?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Force applied to a clenched fist
Direct force to the fifth digit held in extension
Sudden hyperextension of the fifth digit held in flexion
Lateral force applied to the fifth digit

questions.solution:
This patient presents after being found down with right-hand swelling, scattered abrasions, and a head laceration. Given these findings, he was likely involved in a physical altercation. Imaging demonstrates a fracture of the distal end of the fifth metacarpal, which is consistent with a boxer fracture. The most common mechanism of action leading to this injury pattern is a direct force applied to a clenched fist.  

Boxer fractures are common and represent approximately 10% of all hand fractures. It is most commonly seen amongst boxers (hence the name), individuals involved in physical altercations, and athletes participating in contact sports (e.g., football, rugby). The most common mechanism of injury for this fracture involves axial pressure applied to the metacarpal bone when the fist is in a clenched position.

Clinically, patients with boxer fractures will often experience dorsal hand pain, swelling, and possible deformity over the fifth knuckle. Treatment is generally conservative and involves analgesia with closed reduction and placement in an ulnar gutter splint. Surgical referral is indicated for severe deformity or a high degree of displacement and angulation.

Option Analysis

✅ Force applied to a clenched fist  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fall on an outstretched hand  :
Incorrect: Fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH) represents the major mechanism of injury for many wrist pathologies, including scaphoid and distal radius fractures. However, this patient has a characteristic fracture of the fifth metacarpal, which is suggestive of a boxer fracture, most commonly caused by a direct force applied to a clenched fist.  
❌ Direct force to the fifth digit held in extension  :
Incorrect: A direct force to the fifth digit held in extension would result in a Mallet finger caused by rupture of the extensor tendon where it attaches to the distal phalanx. In contrast, this patient’s imaging shows a fracture of the fifth metacarpal bone.  
❌ Sudden hyperextension of the fifth digit held in flexion  :
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action attributed to the Jersey finger, injuring the flexor digitorum profundus tendon as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. In contrast, this patient’s imaging shows a fracture of the fifth metacarpal bone.  
❌ Lateral force applied to the fifth digit  :
Incorrect: A lateral force applied to the fifth digit would likely result in a dislocation injury rather than a fracture.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute left shoulder pain. The patient was lowering himself from a pullup at the gym when he suddenly felt a “pop” followed by acute pain in the anterior left shoulder. The patient has a history of left supraspinatus tendinopathy that was treated with physical therapy. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Physical examination reveals ecchymosis, swelling, and tenderness over the anterior left deltoid. The patient's arm is pronated and flexed at the elbow to 90 degrees. The examiner attempts to supinate the arm against resistance, which elicits shoulder pain. A radiograph of the shoulder is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii
Rupture of the short-head of the biceps brachii

questions.solution:
This patient presents with anterior shoulder pain after a load is applied during eccentric contraction of the biceps brachii. Physical examination demonstrates a positive Yergason test. In combination, these findings are consistent with tendinopathy of the long-head of the biceps brachii.

Tear or rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii is associated with an eccentric force applied to a contracted biceps tendon. Patients often recall a “snap” or “pop” followed by ecchymosis, swelling, and pain immediately after the inciting mechanism of injury. Additionally, patients will often have a bulbous mass in the upper arm due to excessive retraction of the biceps muscle belly. This finding is known as a "Popeye deformity."

Specific examination findings may include a positive Yergason test, wherein pain is reproduced at the anterior shoulder when the patient attempts to supinate the arm against resistance after the examiner places the patient's arm in pronation and 90 degree flexion at the elbow. In addition, an exam maneuver known as the Speed test may also yield a positive test. In this exam, the patient's arm is extended in full supination with the shoulder flexed, and the patient is asked to elevate the arm against a resistive force; a positive test will produce the pain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Supraspinatus tear  :
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of rotator cuff injury, physical examination demonstrates a positive Yergason test. This physical examination maneuver has a high specificity for biceps injury. In contrast, a supraspinatus injury would demonstrate a positive empty can test.  
❌ Subacromial bursitis  :
Incorrect: Subacromial bursitis falls into the category of rotator cuff impingement injuries and presents with chronic shoulder pain. Patients with subacromial bursitis will demonstrate limited active range of motion but preserved passive range of motion.  
❌ Acromioclavicular joint separation  :
Incorrect: Acromioclavicular joint separation most commonly occurs due to a direct force to the lateral aspect of the shoulder while the arm is held in adduction. Clinical features include swelling and pain over the lateral aspect of the shoulder. Radiography will show widening of the acromioclavicular joint.  
❌ Rupture of the short-head of the biceps brachii  :
Incorrect: Rupture of the short-head of the biceps brachii is less common than rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii. A common mechanism of injury involves sudden forceful extension of the person's flexed elbow when the biceps muscle is fully contracted. Physical examination findings will demonstrate swelling of the antecubital fossa and a positive hook test.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall on an outstretched hand. During the fall, the patient hyperextended his right wrist and felt a “pop.” He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals ecchymosis and swelling of the volar aspect of the right wrist. A lateral radiograph of the right wrist is obtained and shown below. Which of the following anatomic structures is at risk of injury based on this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
After a fall onto an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury), this patient presents with evidence of volar swelling and deformity. Imaging demonstrates the “spilled teacup” sign, pathognomonic for a lunate dislocation.

Lunate dislocations represent a relatively uncommon pattern of wrist injuries, but the most common mechanism of injury involves a FOOSH injury or high-energy trauma. The capitate stays in place in lunate dislocations, while the lunate is displaced. A closely related injury pattern is perilunate dislocation, in which the lunate stays, but the capitate is displaced.

Clinically, lunate dislocations present with pain on the volar-radial aspect of the wrist, with associated pain and swelling. Assessment of median nerve function is paramount in patients with this injury pattern, as lunate dislocations are often associated with compressive radiculopathy of the nerve. The most common radiographic feature associated with lunate dislocations is the spilled tea-cup sign on lateral x-rays, which represents the lunate being pushed off the radius into the palm.  

Option Analysis

✅ Median nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Radial nerve  :
Incorrect: Radial nerve injury does not typically occur with lunate dislocations. Instead, it more commonly occurs with humeral shaft fractures.  
❌ Ulnar nerve  :
Incorrect: Injury to the ulnar nerve more commonly occurs due to injury to the hook of the hamate, not the lunate.  
❌ Radial artery  :
Incorrect: Radial artery injuries are uncommon in the setting of lunate dislocations.  
❌ Ulnar collateral ligament  :
Incorrect: The ulnar collateral ligament is not typically damaged in the setting of lunate dislocations.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining an injury to the right middle finger. The patient was outside playing baseball with his friends when he sustained the injury. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 115/79 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. Physical examination demonstrates an inability to extend the right middle finger's distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. Flexion at the DIP joint of this digit is preserved. A picture of the patient’s hand is demonstrated below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of injury associated with this pathology?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Direct force to the third digit held in extension
Lateral force applied to the third digit
Sudden hyperextension of the third digit held in flexion
Direct force applied to a clenched fist

questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of a mallet finger (baseball finger), which refers to an injury to the extensor digitorum as it crosses the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. The most common mechanism of injury associated with this pathology is a direct force to the digit held in extension. This injury pattern results in an inability to extend the finger at the DIP joint.

Mallet finger is the most common closed tendon injury of the finger and is a common injury pattern in baseball players. The mechanism of injury involves a direct force to a digit held in extension, such as when a baseball strikes the distal end of the finger resulting in forced flexion of the DIP joint. Clinically, this manifests with pain and swelling over the dorsum of the DIP joint, DIP flexion deformity, and an inability to extend the DIP joint actively.

Treatment for a simple mallet finger (without an associated fracture) involves splinting the finger in extension for six to eight weeks. If left in flexion, the finger is more prone to developing osteoarthritis or a swan neck deformity. If the mallet finger is associated with a fracture, surgical referral, in addition to splinting, is indicated.

Option Analysis

✅ Direct force to the third digit held in extension  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral force applied to the third digit  :
Incorrect: A lateral force applied to the third digit would likely result in a dislocation injury, manifesting with difficulty both flexing and extending the affected joint.  
❌ Fall on an outstretched hand  :
Incorrect: Wrist pathologies (e.g., scaphoid fracture, distal radius fracture) can arise following a fall onto an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury). In contrast, this patient presents with drooping and an inability to extend the fingertip, which is more consistent with a mallet finger.  
❌ Sudden hyperextension of the third digit held in flexion  :
Incorrect: This mechanism of action will result in injury to the flexor digitorum profundus tendon as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. Patients with this injury pattern will extend, but not flex, the fingertip.  
❌ Direct force applied to a clenched fist  :
Incorrect: A direct force applied to a clenched fist will often fracture the fifth metacarpal. This fracture pattern is termed a boxer fracture. In contrast, this patient presents with drooping and an inability to extend the fingertip, which is more consistent with a mallet finger.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate left wrist pain. The patient was cleaning the bathroom when she slipped, fell, and landed on an outstretched left arm. She was subsequently unable to move her left wrist due to pain. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, and she takes amlodipine daily. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates swelling and deformity of the left wrist. Plain films of the left wrist are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

Image reproduced from Radiopedia.
questions.solution:
This older patient presents after a fall on an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury). Imaging of the wrist demonstrates a distal radius fracture with dorsal angulation, which is consistent with a Colles fracture.

Colles fractures are the most common wrist fracture and typically occur after sports-related injuries in younger patients or low-energy trauma in older patients with osteoporosis. A fracture will appear on plain films of the distal radius, with varying degrees of impaction, displacement, and associated intra-articular fractures. The most common mechanism of injury involves a fall on an outstretched hand, such that the direction of force displaces the radial fragment dorsally.

Smith fractures are distal radius fractures with volar angulation. The most common mechanism of injury for this fracture pattern is falling onto flexed wrists. This contrasts to Colles fractures, wherein the wrist is held in extension during the fall. Smith fractures can be diagnosed via plain films.

Clinically, both fracture patterns will demonstrate swelling and deformity of the wrist with limited passive and active range of motion due to pain. Assessment of neurovascular status should take place before and after closed reduction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Colles fracture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Smith fracture:
Incorrect: A Smith fracture involves volar displacement of the distal radius fracture fragment. In contrast, this patient’s radiograph demonstrates dorsal displacement of the distal radius fracture fragment.  
❌ Galeazzi fracture  :
Incorrect: A Galeazzi fracture is a transverse dorsally displaced fracture of the mid-radius with subsequent widening of the distal radio-ulnar joint.  
❌ Monteggia fracture:
Incorrect: Monteggia fractures are ulnar fractures with associated dislocation of the radial head from its articulation with the capitellum.  
❌ Bennett fracture:
Incorrect: A Bennett fracture occurs at the base of the first metacarpal. It is an intraarticular fracture wherein the palmar ulnar aspect of the first metacarpal base is separated from the remainder of the first metacarpal.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with worsening right shoulder pain. The patient has difficulty pulling items off the shelf and can no longer do overhead weight exercises. Additionally, the pain often wakes the patient from sleep at night, especially when she lies on the right shoulder. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. On physical examination, the shoulder and elbow are placed at 90 degrees of flexion in front of the body. The patient experiences pain when the examiner internally rotates the shoulder. The left shoulder has a full range of motion. There is no reproducible tenderness on palpation or flexion of the cervical spine. A radiograph of the right shoulder is shown below:  


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with intermittent shoulder pain that worsens with overhead movements, but she has a normal shoulder radiograph. In addition, she has a positive Hawkins test, which is indicative of rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy.

Rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy is a common cause of shoulder pain. It often occurs due to repetitive overhead activity that results in inflammation of the rotator cuff tendons. Patients often describe pain over the lateral deltoid that is worse with overhead activity or while lying on the affected shoulder at night.

Physical examination will often demonstrate a positive Neer impingement test, wherein the patient experiences pain as the arm is passively flexed while in internal rotation. In addition, the Hawkins test can be used to diagnose rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy. In this test, the examiner passively positions the shoulder and elbow at 90 degrees of flexion in front of the body, and patients will experience pain when the examiner passively internally rotates the shoulder.

Treatment of rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy is centered on conservative management with physical therapy, analgesia, and rest.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rotator cuff tendinopathy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Adhesive capsulitis  :
Incorrect: Adhesive capsulitis, also known as “frozen shoulder syndrome,” manifests with gross stiffness of the shoulder and nagging pain. Physical examination will demonstrate significant reductions in active and passive range of motion in two or more planes of movement.  
❌ Osteoarthritis  :
Incorrect: This patient’s above radiograph does not demonstrate evidence of glenohumeral joint space narrowing or bony erosion. Thus osteoarthritis is unlikely to be the cause of this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Biceps tendinopathy  :
Incorrect: Biceps tendinopathy manifests with pain focused in the anterior shoulder with radiation distally over the biceps muscle.  
❌ Cervical spondylosis  :
Incorrect: Cervical spondylosis can mimic rotator cuff tendinopathy. However, in this condition, pain is often localized over the cervical spine, and patients can have a positive Spurling test (reproduction of symptoms when the patient’s head is turned towards the affected side, and pressure is applied to the top of the head).

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with worsening left shoulder pain. The pain has been present for years, but she now is having difficulty writing on the chalkboard during her elementary school classes. The patient was a professional soccer player in her early adulthood, and she sustained a rotator cuff injury that was repaired surgically. Medical history is also notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On physical examination, the patient has marked tenderness to palpation at the glenohumeral joint and limited abduction and external rotation secondary to pain. A radiograph of the left shoulder is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic left shoulder pain and a limited range of motion due to pain. The patient’s radiograph demonstrates glenohumeral joint space narrowing, sclerosis, and osteophyte formation. These findings are consistent with glenohumeral osteoarthritis.

Glenohumeral osteoarthritis is a relatively uncommon form of osteoarthritis. However, it more commonly occurs in older females with a history of prior shoulder surgery, injury, or trauma. Conditions that predispose to glenohumeral osteoarthritis include shoulder dislocation, rotator cuff tears, rheumatoid arthritis, and humeral head/neck fracture.

Most cases of glenohumeral osteoarthritis present clinically with chronic, nagging, and deep shoulder pain that is exacerbated with movement. Shoulder mobility is typically limited due to pain, especially during abduction and external rotation. Treatment involves analgesia and shoulder replacement surgery in advanced cases of the disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ Glenohumeral osteoarthritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteosarcoma  :
Incorrect: Osteosarcoma arises from pleomorphic osteoid producing cells and presents as a painful mass or pathologic fracture. Radiographic features include lytic bone lesions and a sunburst pattern, which is secondary to aggressive periosteal reaction.  
❌ Supraspinatus tendinopathy  :
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of rotator cuff injury, the physical examination and radiograph are more consistent with glenohumeral osteoarthritis.  
❌ Cervical spondylosis  :
Incorrect: Cervical spondylosis can mimic disorders of the glenohumeral joint. However, in this condition, pain is more often localized over the cervical spine. In addition, patients with cervical spondylosis may have a positive Spurling test (in which symptoms are reproduced when the patient’s head is turned towards the affected side, and pressure is applied to the top of the head).  
❌ Adhesive capsulitis  :
Incorrect: Adhesive capsulitis, also known as “frozen shoulder syndrome,” manifests with gross stiffness of the shoulder and nagging pain. Physical examination will demonstrate significant reductions in active and passive range of motion in two or more planes of movement. It can be differentiated from osteoarthritis as early disease typically demonstrates a normal shoulder radiograph (unlike that of this patient) and presents subacutely over the course of days to weeks (whereas this patient’s symptoms are chronic).

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department with left-sided shoulder pain. The patient was playing flag football when he tripped and fell on an outstretched left arm. Physical examination is notable for a gap along the lateral edge of the left acromion process. The left arm is in slight abduction and external rotation. A radiograph of the shoulder is obtained and shown below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute onset shoulder pain after falling on an outstretched arm. Physical examination is notable for a visible deformity of the left shoulder, and radiography demonstrates an anteriorly displaced glenohumeral head on the axillary Y-view. These findings are consistent with an anterior shoulder dislocation.

Anterior shoulder dislocations are a common orthopedic injury and typically occur after a fall onto an outstretched arm. Clinically, patients may present with a visible deformity of the shoulder and a “squared appearance” compared to the contralateral shoulder. In addition, patients will typically hold their arm in slight abduction and external rotation. Radiographs will demonstrate an anteriorly displaced humeral head on the axillary Y-view.

Complications include axillary artery and nerve injury. As a result, patients should be assessed for neurovascular injury both pre- and post-reduction. In addition, associated bony injuries to the glenohumeral joint include the Hill-Sachs deformity (posterolateral humeral head compression fracture) and Bankart lesions (injury to the inferior glenoid labrum).

In contrast, posterior shoulder dislocations are rare and most commonly occur due to prolonged seizures, high speed motor vehicle accidents, or lightning injuries. Clinically, they are less commonly associated with a gross deformity. However, patients may demonstrate prominence of the coracoid process or posterior shoulder. In addition, the arm is often held in internal rotation. Complications include rotator cuff/labrum tears and humeral fractures.  

Option Analysis

✅ Anterior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Posterior shoulder dislocations are rare but can occur in the setting of high speed motor vehicle accidents, status epilepticus, and lightning injuries. It will demonstrate a posteriorly displaced humeral head on the axillary Y-view. In contrast, this patient’s shoulder radiograph demonstrates an anteriorly displaced humeral head.  
❌ Inferior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Inferior glenohumeral joint dislocations occur due to axial loading while the arm is fully abducted. Patients will have their arm fully abducted with the elbow flexed above their head. Plain films will demonstrate the humeral head inferior to the glenoid.  
❌ Sternoclavicular joint separation  :
Incorrect: Sternoclavicular joint separation involves a tear in the sterno-clavicular ligaments and is classified as either anterior or posterior. This radiograph does not capture the sterno-clavicular joint.  
❌ Superior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Superior glenohumeral joint dislocations are a rare occurrence and are due to a force in the anterior and superior direction.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to her family medicine physician for a routine checkup after sustaining a right tibia fracture from a motor vehicle accident one month ago. She has been using crutches frequently for ambulation and endorses decreased sensation over her right dorsoradial arm and an inability to extend her right wrist, thumb, and fingers. The patient states that her symptoms subside with rest. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings of radial nerve compression (often known as “Saturday night palsy”).   Patients with this condition often have a history of persistent compression applied to the axilla, either by a physical object such as crutches or via prolonged abduction of the arm (e.g. falling asleep on an outstretched arm).

Patients with radial nerve compression often endorse absent or decreased sensation on the dorsoradial side of the hand and wrist, in addition to the inability to extend their wrist, thumb, and fingers.
