When the hand is placed in pronation, the wrist and hand will drop (a finding known as “wrist drop”)—approximately 92% of patients suffering from radial nerve compression resolve with observation alone.  

Option Analysis

❌ C7 nerve root injury  :
Incorrect: An isolated injury to the C7 nerve root is rare and low-yield for examination purposes. On rare occasions, injury to the C7 nerve root is associated with Erb palsy.  
❌ Carpal tunnel syndrome  :
Incorrect: This patient’s disease etiology and symptomatology are not congruent with findings of carpal tunnel syndrome, which presents with median nerve neuropathy most commonly in patients with underlying diabetes, hypothyroidism, or repetitive hand motions.  
✅ Radial nerve injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ulnar nerve injury  :
Incorrect: Ulnar nerve injury presents with an ulnar claw hand, rather than complete wrist drop as observed in this patient’s presentation.  
❌ C5-C6 nerve root injury  :
Incorrect: Upper brachial plexus injuries often occur from lateral flexion of the neck, causing partial or complete laceration of cervical nerve roots C5-6. Injury to these nerve roots results in Erb palsy, wherein the wrist is flexed, the forearm is extended, and the arm is internally rotated.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with worsening left shoulder pain. The patient is an avid weightlifter. However, over the past several months, he has experienced worsening left shoulder pain that is exacerbated by overhead movements. He has no history of major trauma or surgery. On physical examination, the patient has weakness in the left shoulder after downward pressure is applied while both arms are at 90° elevation in the scapular plane with full internal rotation. Which of the following anatomic structures is most likely to be disrupted given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with left shoulder pain that is exacerbated by overhead activities. There is reproducible weakness with the empty can test. These findings are consistent with rotator cuff injury. The most commonly injured rotator cuff muscle is the supraspinatus.

The rotator cuff muscles include the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis. These muscles coordinate complex movements of the shoulder joint and are commonly injured in athletes as well as older adults, resulting in a rotator cuff injury. The etiology of injury is often multifactorial and often stems from repetitive movements against resistance, rather than a single episode of trauma or injury to the shoulder.

The majority of rotator cuff injuries involve the supraspinatus, which is responsible for abduction of the arm. Patients often describe nagging pain localized to the deltoid that worsens with overhead movements. If a full thickness tear is present, patients may have weakness or an inability to raise the arm overhead.

The empty can test (also termed Jobe test) has a high specificity for supraspinatus injuries. In this test, the patient is placed in a standing or sitting position, and the arm is raised parallel to the ground in the scapular plane with the arm rotated to full internal rotation. Once rotated, the clinician pushes down on either the wrist or elbow, and the patient is instructed to resist the downward pressure. Weakness or pain in the tested shoulder elicits a positive test.  

Option Analysis

✅ Supraspinatus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Subscapularis  :
Incorrect: While the subscapularis muscle is a part of the rotator cuff muscle group, it is less commonly injured than the supraspinatus muscle. The patient has an abnormal empty can test, which is more consistent with the presentation of a supraspinatus tear.  
❌ Infraspinatus  :
Incorrect: The infraspinatus is less commonly injured than the supraspinatus. In addition, this patient has an abnormal empty can test, which is more consistent with the presentation of a supraspinatus tear.  
❌ Teres minor  :
Incorrect: The teres minor is less commonly injured than the supraspinatus. In addition, this patient has an abnormal empty can test, which is more consistent with the presentation of a supraspinatus tear.  
❌ Biceps brachii  :
Incorrect: The biceps brachii is not a part of the rotator cuff muscle group.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man in army training is brought to the medic station to evaluate right upper extremity pain. The patient was repelling when he lost control of his rope, forcefully grabbing it with an outstretched right hand. The patient endorses pain in the right shoulder, axilla, and right hand. Temperature is 97 F° (36.1 C°), pulse is 130/min, and blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. The right palm has several superficial abrasions. The sensation of all fingers is intact except for the fifth digit. He cannot extend the right fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joint or flex the fingers at the distal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic location of this patient’s lesion?
questions.solution:
This patient has a brachial plexus injury, likely at the C8-T1 nerve roots, with characteristic features of an injury pattern known as Klumpke palsy. Klumpke palsy is the most common form of lower brachial plexus injury, with a mechanism that typically involves hyperabduction of the arm. In Klumpke palsy, patients develop a phenomenon known as “claw hand,” where the metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP) are unable to extend, and both the proximal interphalangeal joints (PIP) and distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) remain flexed. These findings result from subsequent paralysis of the intrinsic muscles of the hand and the flexors of the wrist and fingers–notably the flexor carpi ulnaris and ulnar half of the flexor digitorum profundus. Sensory deficits occur along with the 5th digit and the medial aspect of the forearm and arm.

Ulnar nerve injury is another common type of lower brachial plexus injury that presents with a sensory deficit of the 5th and medial half of the 4th digit. Motor deficit includes an “ulnar claw,” wherein the affected 4th and 5th digits cannot extend at the DIP and PIP joints, with the MCP stuck in sustained flexion. Treatment involves immobilization of the affected limb and fingers, physiotherapy, and surgery.  

Option Analysis

❌ C5-C6 nerve roots  :
Incorrect: Lesions at this level in the brachial plexus are associated with Erb palsy, not Klumpke palsy. This condition presents as a flexed wrist, extended forearm, and internally rotated arm.  
❌ Ulnar nerve  :
Incorrect: A lesion of the ulnar nerve alone would result in sensory loss to the 5th digit and half of the 4th digit.  
❌ Median nerve  :
Incorrect: A median nerve lesion would result in sensory loss to the palm and first four fingers. This patient’s pathology results in loss of function at the PIP, MCP, and DIP joints.  
❌ C7 nerve root  :
Incorrect: An isolated injury to the C7 nerve root is rare and low-yield for examination purposes. On rare occasions, injury to the C7 nerve root is associated with Erb palsy.  
✅ C8-T1 nerve roots  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents to the emergency room to evaluate severe left knee pain. An hour ago, he jumped during a football game to catch the ball and was tackled by another player. The patient felt severe left knee pain immediately afterward. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 112/83 mmHg, and pulse is 98/min. Physical examination reveals increased anterior gliding of the left tibia relative to the femur when the knee is flexed at 90 degrees. Which of the following is true regarding the ligament most likely injured in this patient?

choices.text: It connects from the lateral femoral condyle to the anterior tibia.
It connects from the medial femoral condyle to the anterior tibia.
It connects from the lateral femoral condyle to the posterior tibia.
It connects from the medial femoral condyle to the posterior tibia.
It connects from the lateral femur to the fibula.

questions.solution:
This patient has most likely injured the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL), given the anterior drawer test (increased anterior gliding of the tibia relative to the femur) is positive.    

The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) and posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) are two ligaments that attach the tibia to the femur at the knee joint. The cruciate ligaments are major ligaments that stabilize the knee joint and prevent excessive movement of the tibia relative to the femur during joint movement.    

The ACL can be identified anteriorly, connecting the lateral femoral condyle to the anterior tibia. The function of the ACL is to prevent anterior sliding of the tibia relative to the femur. When injured, there is increased gliding of the tibia relative to the femur at 90 degrees. This physical examination maneuver is called the anterior drawer test and indicates ACL injury.    

In contrast, the PCL runs posteriorly. It connects the medial femoral condyle to the posterior tibia. The PCL prevents posterior gliding of the tibia relative to the femur. When the PCL is injured, there will be increased posterior gliding of the tibia relative to the femur when the knee is bent at 90 degrees. This physical examination maneuver is termed the positive posterior drawer test and indicates PCL injury.

Option Analysis

✅ It connects from the lateral femoral condyle to the anterior tibia.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ It connects from the medial femoral condyle to the anterior tibia. :
Incorrect: This patient has most likely injured his anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). The ACL connects the lateral (not medial) femoral condyle to the anterior tibia.  
❌ It connects from the lateral femoral condyle to the posterior tibia. :
Incorrect: This patient has most likely injured his anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). The ACL connects the lateral femoral condyle to the anterior (not posterior) tibia.  
❌ It connects from the medial femoral condyle to the posterior tibia. :
Incorrect: The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) connects the medial femoral condyle to the posterior tibia. However, this patient has increased anterior gliding of the tibia relative to the femur, which indicates that the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is injured, not the PCL.  
❌  It connects from the lateral femur to the fibula. :
Incorrect: The lateral collateral ligament (LCL) connects from the lateral femur to the fibula. However, a positive anterior drawer test indicates that the anterior collateral ligament (ACL) is injured, not the LCL.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a hand injury. The patient was jogging when he tripped and fell onto an area of concrete with scattered glass shards. He sustained lacerations to the left hand. He is otherwise healthy and does not take medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 115/78 mmHg, and pulse is 103/min. Visual inspection of the left hand demonstrates a 4 cm laceration extending from the base of the hypothenar eminence to the thenar eminence. Which of the following should be evaluated to assess for underlying nerve injury?

choices.text: Sensation to the first, second, and third digits
Sensation to the medial fourth digit and entire fifth digit

questions.solution:
This patient sustained a laceration to the palm, which may lead to injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve that travels superficially in the palm. Among the physical examination maneuvers listed, assessment of active thumb abduction is paramount in evaluating for potential injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve.

Assessment of hand motor and sensory function after an injury is essential for appropriate treatment, disposition, and follow-up. All patients should undergo an assessment of strength, radial, ulnar, and digital pulses characterization, and a sensory examination. Patients with evidence of deficits should be assessed for associated tendinous, vascular, or nerve injury and, if discovered, should undergo consultation with a hand surgeon.

The median nerve provides sensation to the palmar aspect of the first, second, third, and half of the fourth digit. In addition, the nerve provides motor innervation to muscles in the thenar eminence and flexor muscles of the hand and wrist.

Injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve will manifest with pure motor deficits, as it innervates the three muscles of the thenar eminence: the abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, and the superficial head of the flexor pollicis brevis. 

Option Analysis

✅ Active thumb abduction  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sensation to the first, second, and third digits  :
Incorrect: This patient sustained a laceration of the palm, which can result in injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve. If the nerve is injured, patients will develop motor dysfunction without sensory deficits.  
❌ Active extension of the digits  :
Incorrect: Extension of the digits of the hand is mediated via the radial nerve, which courses on the dorsal aspect of the hand, not the palmar aspect.  
❌ Sensation to the medial fourth digit and entire fifth digit  :
Incorrect: This patient sustained a laceration of the palm, which can result in injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve. Sensation to these digits is mediated by the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve.  
❌ Active extension of the wrist  :
Incorrect: Extension of the wrist is mediated by the radial nerve, which courses on the dorsal aspect of the wrist, not the palmar aspect of the hand.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office to evaluate left hand and fingers' pain, tingling, and numbness. The patient reports that the pain worsens at night and now interferes with typing while working as an office secretary. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the left hand shows a loss of sensation over the dorsal and palmar aspects of lateral 3½ fingers, along with weakness of thumb flexion and opposition. Sensation over the thenar eminence is intact. The patient is subsequently referred for a surgical release procedure. The affected nerve in this patient was most likely injured at which of the following locations?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sensory loss over the lateral 3½ fingers and thumb flexion and opposition weakness, consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).



The carpal tunnel is a deep anatomic space within the wrist formed between the carpal bones and transverse carpal ligament. CTS occurs when this space narrows and compresses the median nerve. Risk factors for this condition include repetitive wrist activity use (e.g. keyboard typing), diabetes mellitus, and hypothyroidism. Patients typically present with pain and paraesthesias in the radial 3½ digits, weakness of the first and second lumbrical, thenar atrophy, and weakness of thumb abduction and opposition. The palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve arises proximal to and does not pass through the carpal tunnel; thus sensation in the central palm remains intact.  

In the case of median nerve injury at the wrist (e.g. wrist laceration), patients often present with “median claw,” meaning when the patient attempts to extend the fingers, the index and middle fingers extend at the MCP. Still, the DIP and PIP remain flexed due to finger flexor non-opposition.  

Proximal median nerve injury can occur due to a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. In addition to the deficits observed in a distal lesion, all finger flexors for the 2nd and 3rd digits are also affected (flexor digitorum superficialis and the lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus). Patients can only flex the 4th and 5th digits when asked to make a fist. This is referred to as the benediction sign or the “Pope’s blessing.”  



Option Analysis

✅ Carpal tunnel:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Supinator muscle:
Incorrect: The deep branch of the radial nerve can be injured as it passes through the supinator muscle secondary to repetitive pronation/supination (use of screwdrivers). Patients typically present with weakness of finger and thumb extension (without wrist drop and preserved sensations). This patient’s symptoms are suggestive of median nerve entrapment.
❌ Hook of the hamate:
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve is susceptible to injury in patients with a fracture of the hook of the hamate and results in loss of abduction and adduction of the fingers. Injury to this nerve will not result in sensory loss over the lateral half of the fingers.  
❌ Axilla:
Incorrect: The radial nerve can be injured in the axilla (Saturday night palsy) and presents with weakness in the forearm, hand, and finger extensor muscles and sensory loss over the posterior arm, forearm and dorsolateral hand. Weakness of thumb flexion and opposition is suggestive of median nerve injury.
❌ Coracobrachialis:
Incorrect: The coracobrachialis is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve. Injury to this nerve would result in weakness in forearm flexion and supination and sensory loss over the lateral forearm.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after sustaining a shoulder injury while playing football. The patient was diving towards the end-zone when another player collided directly with his left shoulder. On physical examination, the patient is holding the left arm adducted. Swelling is present over the lateral aspect of the left shoulder. A radiograph of the left shoulder is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lateral shoulder pain after a direct blow to the acromioclavicular joint. The radiograph demonstrates widening of the acromioclavicular joint, which is consistent with acromioclavicular joint separation.

Acromioclavicular joint separation is a common injury. It is most often seen in young males engaged in bicycle accidents or high impact sports such as football. The most common mechanism of injury occurs due to a direct blow to the lateral aspect of the shoulder while the arm is held in adduction.

Clinical features include swelling and tenderness to the lateral aspect of the shoulder. A physical examination maneuver known as the crossover test, wherein passive cross-body adduction of the arm compresses the acromioclavicular joint, may elicit pain. Radiography will demonstrate widening of the acromioclavicular joint, superior displacement of the clavicle, and widening of the coracoclavicular ligament.

Injuries to the acromioclavicular joint are classified based on the degree of damage sustained by the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments. In general, most injuries are managed nonoperatively via placement in a sling and immobilization.  

Option Analysis

✅ Acromioclavicular separation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sternoclavicular separation  :
Incorrect: Sternoclavicular joint separations will often demonstrate a deformity and swelling along the medial aspect of the clavicle. They are more often anterior and without significant complications. Posterior dislocations are associated with increased morbidity due to their propensity to disrupt vascular structures.  
❌ Posterior shoulder dislocation  :
Incorrect: Posterior shoulder dislocations are rare but can occur in the setting of high speed motor vehicle accidents, status epilepticus, and lightning injuries. Plain films will demonstrate a posteriorly displaced humeral head on the axillary Y-view.  
❌ Anterior shoulder dislocation  :
Incorrect: Anterior shoulder dislocations are the most common form of shoulder dislocation and present with a squared-off appearance of the shoulder. The dislocated arm is typically in slight abduction and external rotation. The axillary Y-view will demonstrate an anteriorly placed humeral head relative to the glenoid fossa.  
❌ Clavicle fracture  :
Incorrect: There is no evidence of a left clavicle fracture on this patient’s radiograph.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with worsening left shoulder pain. He can no longer do bench presses or shoulder presses at the gym due to weakness and pain. The pain is primarily located over the lateral shoulder, is worse at night, and is preventing him from obtaining adequate rest. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. He has no history of recent trauma or surgeries to the left shoulder. The patient subsequently undergoes a MRI of the left shoulder, which reveals the following:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following physical examination maneuvers is most likely to yield a positive test, given this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with worsening left shoulder pain and weakness. MRI imaging demonstrates a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon. Of the physical examination techniques listed, the one most likely to demonstrate a positive finding is the empty can test.

The shoulder is made up of the rotator cuff muscles, the glenohumeral and acromioclavicular ligaments, and connective tissue. In the assessment of shoulder pain, several tests can aid in the diagnosis of a specific injury. For instance, the empty can test (also termed Jobe test) has a high specificity for supraspinatus injuries. In this test, the patient is placed in a standing or sitting position, and the arm is raised parallel to the ground in the scapular plane and fully internally rotated. Once rotated, the clinician pushes down on either the wrist or elbow, and the patient is instructed to resist the downward force. Weakness or pain in the tested shoulder represents a positive test result.

Another test known as the full can test also assesses for supraspinatus instability. It is performed in the same manner as the empty can test, with the only difference being that the patient's arms are not rotated to full internal rotation (e.g. thumbs are up).

Additional tests include the Neer test and Hawkins-Kennedy test, which assess for subacromial impingement syndrome. The Scarf test assesses for stability of the acromioclavicular joint and is commonly positive with partial or full tears of the acromioclavicular or coracoclavicular ligaments.  

Option Analysis

✅ Empty can test  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lift off test  :
Incorrect: The lift off test is performed to assess for instability of the subscapularis. In this test, the patient actively lifts the dorsum of the hand off the back with resistance. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.  
❌ Scarf test  :
Incorrect: The Scarf test is used to assess for stability of the acromioclavicular joint. It is performed by passively adducting the patient's arm across the body horizontally, approximating the elbow to the contralateral shoulder. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.  
❌ Neer test  :
Incorrect: The Neer test is used to assess for subacromial impingement syndrome. This test is performed by stabilizing the patient's scapula with one hand and passively flexing the arm while it is internally rotated. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.  
❌ Yergason test  :
Incorrect: The Yergason test is used to assess for tear or rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii. In this test, pain is reproduced at the anterior shoulder as the patient attempts to supinate the arm against resistance when the arm is pronated and flexed at the elbow to 90 degrees. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to his primary care physician to evaluate the sudden onset of numbness and tingling in the right upper extremity following a workout. The patient was performing sit-ups when he experienced a sharp pain in his neck, followed by numbness and tingling in his right hand. He does not have any symptoms while at rest. He reports several similar episodes in the past. He is a bodybuilder. Vital signs are within normal limits. The right lateral neck appears larger when compared to the left lateral neck. The patient has no spinal tenderness to palpation. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), a condition causing transient numbness and tingling in the upper extremity. Specifically, this patient likely suffers from neurogenic thoracic outlet syndrome due to hypertrophy of the anterior scalene, given his history of bodybuilding.

TOS is an umbrella term that encompasses compression of one or multiple of the following structures: the brachial plexus, subclavian vein, or subclavian artery. Etiologies of TOS include anterior scalene hypertrophy, cervical rib injuries, trauma, tumors, or repetitive motion injuries of the shoulder. Additional findings of various types of TOS are summarized in the table below.  



Option Analysis

✅ Anterior scalene hypertrophy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Exogenous testosterone use  :
Incorrect: Exogenous testosterone use would not result in this patient’s neurological symptoms.  
❌ Herniated cervical disk:
Incorrect: Lower cervical neck injuries resulting in paresthesias usually occur due to trauma. This patient’s presentation is consistent with an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Cervical rib obstruction  :
Incorrect: Cervical ribs are a cause of thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS); however, it is more likely with this patient’s history of being a bodybuilder that his TOS resulted from hypertrophy of the anterior scalene muscles.  
❌ Pancoast tumor  :
Incorrect: While mass effect from a pancoast tumor is a known cause of thoracic outlet syndrome, this patient’s presentation is suggestive of an alternative etiology.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a right knee injury. The patient was playing rugby when an opposing teammate tackled him. He felt a “pop” in the right knee and experienced pain after that. The patient is otherwise healthy. Physical examination demonstrates a large right knee effusion, a positive anterior drawer test, and a positive valgus stress test. Vital signs are within normal limits. An MRI of the patient's right knee is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of injury that resulted in this patient’s condition?
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Posteriorly directed force on a flexed knee
Varus force applied to the knee
Direct force to the anterior knee

questions.solution:
After being tackled during a rugby match, this patient presents with right knee pain. Physical examination demonstrates positive anterior drawer and valgus stress tests, which are consistent with anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) and medial collateral ligament (MCL) tears respectively. MRI imaging not only reveals these findings but also evidence of meniscal injury with hyperintensity of the medial meniscus. In combination, these injuries constitute the unhappy triad or a “blown knee”.

The unhappy triad is defined as soft tissue injury to the ACL, MCL, and medial meniscus. This injury pattern is typical in contact sports (e.g., rugby, football, hockey) and occurs when the knee sustains a lateral blow while the foot is planted on the ground. Ultimately, this scenario produces an abduction and external rotation mechanism of injury.

Physical examination findings will often include joint effusion and pain with weight bearing.Injury to the ACL can be detected with a positive anterior drawer test, and MCL injury is associated with a positive valgus stress test. Meniscal injuries are often more challenging to detect, a positive McMurray test may be seen. Definitive diagnosis is achieved with MRI where all three injuries can be visualized. Most unhappy triad injuries are treated with surgical repair.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lateral force to the knee:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posteriorly directed force on a flexed knee:
Incorrect: Posterior cruciate ligament injuries are rare and most commonly occur after high-force trauma with a posteriorly directed force on a flexed knee as in dashboard injuries.  
❌ Varus force applied to the knee:
Incorrect: Varus force applied to the knee from a high energy blow to the anteromedial knee which combines hyperextension and extreme varus force typically causes a lateral collateral ligament injury.  
❌ Twisting force at the knee:
Incorrect: Meniscus tears are often produced by a twisting mechanism applied to the knee, such as when turning rapidly or landing from a large jump.  
❌ Direct force to the anterior knee:
Incorrect: This is the most common mechanism of injury in the setting of patellar fractures. Contraction of the quadriceps aids in stabilizing the anterior and posterior ligaments of the knee.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of right anterior leg pain. She recently joined a fitness program that required resistance training and two hours of brisk walking. The pain is worse at the beginning of exercise and decreases throughout the workout. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates diffuse tenderness along the posteromedial aspect of the right shin. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. X-ray of the right lower extremity reveals no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with diffuse tenderness over the posteromedial aspect of the right shin, consistent with medial tibial stress syndrome (MTSS), also known as shin splints.  

MTSS is commonly seen in casual runners or in individuals following sudden changes in physical activity. Other risk factors include flare feet, rigid arches, or exercising with improper or worn-out footwear. MTSS is thought to result from inflammation of the anterior and posterior calf musculature and periostitis of the tibia. The most common symptoms of MTSS include diffuse pain along the posteromedial border of the tibia that worsens with running. It is important to differentiate MTSS from tibial stress fractures, which more commonly present with point tenderness, as the latter have potential complications if not cared for properly. Plain radiographs in patients with MTSS are usually normal.  



Option Analysis

❌ Exertional compartment syndrome:
Incorrect: Exertional compartment syndrome occurs in young athletes secondary to increased compartment pressures with exertion. Patients usually present with aching or burning pain in the leg within ten minutes of exercise that slowly resolves within 30-40 minutes following exercise. Diffuse shin tenderness is not typically present.  
✅ Medial tibial stress syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stress fracture:
Incorrect: Tibial stress fractures can manifest with anterior leg pain, resembling that of medial tibial stress syndrome. This condition commonly occurs in underweight athletes and presents with point tenderness as opposed to diffuse tenderness.   
❌ Common fibular nerve compression:
Incorrect: The common peroneal nerve is susceptible to injury as it courses laterally around the neck of the fibula. Clinically, it presents with weakness of foot dorsiflexion and eversion as well as sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot and lateral shin and between first and second toe.   
❌ Interosseous ligament tear:
Incorrect: Interosseous ligament tear can occur in high ankle strains and presents with anterolateral ankle pain following a rotational force on a dorsiflexed ankle. This condition is commonly associated with fibula fractures. Diffuse tenderness along the posteromedial aspect of the shin is suggestive of medial tibial stress syndrome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of left ankle pain. He was playing soccer when he accidentally rolled his ankle. Since then, he has developed severe left ankle pain and swelling. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an area of ecchymosis and point tenderness over the anterolateral aspect of the left ankle joint. Exacerbation of pain is noted with forced ankle inversion. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with left lateral ankle pain and significant swelling and ecchymosis, following an inversion injury, most likely suffered an ankle sprain.    

Ankle sprains are the most common ankle injury, and the majority involve the lateral ankle ligaments: the anterior talofibular ligament, the calcaneofibular ligament, and the posterior talofibular ligament. Damage to these ligaments occurs following extreme inversion of the ankle with plantar flexion. The most common ankle sprain involves the anterior talofibular ligament and patients typically present with pain and ecchymosis at the anterolateral aspect of the ankle. Eversion injuries are much less common, and can result in an avulsion fracture of the medial malleolus, leading to joint instability and possible nerve injury.  



Option Analysis

✅ Anterior talofibular ligament sprain:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anterior tibialis tendon rupture:
Incorrect: Anterior tibialis tendon rupture is uncommon and presents with "slapping gait," as the patient is unable to actively dorsiflex the ankle, resulting in the foot slapping the ground with each step. An inversion of a plantar-flexed ankle most commonly results in anterior talofibular ligament sprain.  
❌ Syndesmotic sprain:
Incorrect: Syndesmotic sprains usually result from dorsiflexion and/or eversion of the ankle and affects the anterior tibiofibular, the posterior tibiofibular, the transverse tibiofibular ligaments, and the interosseous membrane. Affected patients present with unstable ankles and tenderness at the distal tibiofibular joints.  
❌ Deltoid ligament sprain:
Incorrect: Deltoid ligament sprain is uncommon, but can result from forced eversion of the ankle and an avulsion fracture of the medial malleolus. The pain of a deltoid ligament sprain is accentuated by eversion of the ankle, not inversion.  
❌ Achilles tendon rupture:
Incorrect: The gastrocnemius and the soleus tendon combine to form the Achilles tendon. Its rupture can occur during strenuous physical activities that involve sudden pivots or rapid acceleration. Tenderness and ecchymosis of the Achilles tendon is noted in affected patients.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the right arm. Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination demonstrates a 2 cm stab wound over the medial aspect of the cubital fossa with ongoing brisk, pulsatile bleeding. Neurologic examination demonstrates loss of sensation over the thenar eminence and dorsal and palmar aspects of the lateral 3 1⁄2 fingers. The patient also exhibits inability to flex the joints of the thumb, second and third digits, and inability to pronate the forearm. Injury to which of the following vascular structures is responsible for this patient’s ongoing bleeding?
questions.solution:
This patient’s stab wound is consistent with injury to the brachial artery and the median nerve, which lie next to each other in the cubital fossa. The cubital fossa contains four main vertical structures (lateral to medial): the radial nerve, biceps brachii tendon, brachial artery, and median nerve.   

The axillary artery terminates beyond the teres major's lower margin as it continues down the ventral surface of the arm to become the brachial artery. Once the brachial artery reaches the cubital fossa, it branches into the radial and ulnar arteries. Injury to the brachial artery  at the medial cubital fossa results in pulsatile, brisk bleeding, often with hematoma formation. Associated median nerve injury is common.    

In addition, the cubital fossa is a common site for venous blood sampling and intravenous line placement  due to its prominent and easily accessible veins. The most commonly accessed vein in this region is the median cubital vein, which connects the basilic and cephalic veins and lies superficial to the bicipital aponeurosis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Radial artery:
Incorrect: The brachial artery bifurcates at the inferior portion of the cubital fossa into the radial artery (superficial) and ulnar artery (deeper). The radial artery accompanies the superficial branch of the radial nerve in the forearm. This patient has evidence of median nerve injury, which lies close to the brachial artery in the medial aspect of the cubital fossa.  
✅ Brachial artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ulnar artery:
Incorrect: The brachial artery bifurcates at the inferior portion of the cubital fossa into the radial artery (superficial) and ulnar artery (deeper). The radial artery accompanies the superficial branch of the radial nerve in the forearm. This patient has evidence of median nerve injury, which lies close to the brachial artery in the medial aspect of the cubital fossa.  
❌ Deep brachial artery:
Incorrect: The deep brachial artery courses posterior to the humerus and is vulnerable to injury with proximal humeral fractures (e.g. humeral shaft fracture).  
❌ Anterior interosseous artery:
Incorrect: The anterior interosseous artery originates in the forearm distal to the cubital fossa.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for severe posterior right thigh pain. He experienced sudden right posterior thigh pain with an associated popping sound while performing a high-kick during martial arts practice. He is unable to bear weight on his right leg. The pain is constant and does not radiate. The patient does not have associated back or buttock pain. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness at the posterior thigh with surrounding ecchymosis. Musculoskeletal examination reveals limited knee flexion and hip extension on the right side. Sensation of the lower extremities is intact, and deep tendon reflexes are +2 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden onset of posterior thigh pain following a high kick which involves forced flexion at the hip with the knee and hip in extension. These findings suggest the patient has most likely suffered a hamstring tear due to an injury of the biceps femoris.  

Hamstring injuries classically occur during high-speed running and following low-speed mechanisms that involve stretching the hip and knee joints at their end ranges of motion. Hamstring strains are classified as either a pull (grade I), partial tear (grade II), or complete tear (grade III). Patients often present with sudden onset, minimal to severe pain over the posterior thigh, sometimes with an associated “popping” sound. Swelling and ecchymosis of the posterior thigh more commonly occur with complete tears. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness, loss of motion, and decreased strength with isometric contraction. An associated avulsion fracture of the ischial tuberosity may also occur with complete hamstring tears.

Option Analysis

❌ Stress fracture:
Incorrect: Prolonged strenuous activity is associated with the development of stress fractures. This condition presents dull, chronic pain of the affected region (e.g. lateral hip pain in femoral head stress fracture). Burning pain and paraesthesia over the lateral thigh suggest cutaneous nerve compression injury.
✅ Biceps femoris tear:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lumbar radiculopathy:
Incorrect: Lumbar radiculopathy can cause posterior thigh pain; however, the pain also typically involves the low back and often radiates below the knee. This patient has evidence of tenderness over the hamstrings better explained by a biceps femoris strain. 
❌ Piriformis muscle spasm:
Incorrect: Piriformis syndrome occurs when the piriformis compresses the sciatic nerve. Symptoms include pain in the buttock area, accompanied by sciatica-like pain, numbness, and weakness that travels down the back of the thigh, calf, and foot.
❌ Hip adductor muscle strains:
Incorrect: Hip adductor strains can occur while sprinting or performing explosive hip movements. This condition typically results in focal pain in the groin or the medial thigh and pain with resisted hip adduction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of left foot pain. The patient recently joined a fitness program that requires her to walk two to three miles daily. The pain begins with her first steps and worsens throughout her daily walks. The pain improves with rest and does not recur with normal daily activities. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and atorvastatin. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a normal left and right foot arch. Direct pressure applied to the bottom of the left heel elicits a sharp pain. Mediolateral squeezing of the heels does not elicit pain. There is tenderness to palpation between the left heel and forefoot when the left toes are dorsiflexed. The remainder of the bilateral lower extremity examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Entrapment of the posterior tibial nerve
Inflammation and degeneration of the plantar aponeurosis

questions.solution:
This patient’s heel pain is most likely due to the inflammation and degeneration of plantar aponeurosis, resulting in plantar fasciitis. 

Plantar aponeurosis is a thick fibrous band that extends from the calcaneus of the foot to the toes, which functions to support the longitudinal arch of the foot. Plantar fasciitis results from chronic overuse and repetitive trauma to aponeurosis near its insertion point at the calcaneus. Risk factors include obesity, excessive foot pronation, excessive running, and prolonged standing. Patients typically present with stabbing heel pain that worsens with walking and may worsen after activity or at the end of the day. Physical examination often demonstrates tenderness at the insertion of the plantar fascia on the calcaneus, especially with toe dorsiflexion. 

The diagnosis is based on clinical findings, but plain radiographs may reveal heel spurs, which are of little diagnostic significance. Plantar fasciitis is a self-limited condition with most resolution of symptoms within twelve months. Initial treatment consists of ice, heat, massage, stretching, and elimination of exacerbating activities.   

Option Analysis

❌ Entrapment of the posterior tibial nerve :
Incorrect: Injury or compression of the posterior tibial nerve at the tarsal tunnel may result in numbness or paraesthesias over the sole of the foot. Pain is reproduced with percussion of the tarsal tunnel (Tinel sign) and not by the palpation of the heel. 
❌ Neuropathic degeneration of interdigital nerves :
Incorrect: Neuropathic degeneration of interdigital nerves can result in a Morton neuroma, which presents with pain between the third and fourth toes on the plantar surface and a clicking sensation upon squeezing the metatarsal joints. Tenderness of the heel with dorsiflexion of the toes is typical of plantar fasciitis. 
✅ Inflammation and degeneration of the plantar aponeurosis :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Overuse injury of the calcaneus :
Incorrect: Calcaneal stress fractures can occur following the initiation of high-impact exercise programs or overuse. It causes pain at the heel that worsens with weight bearing. Pain is often elicited by firm palpation at the lateral and medial aspect of the heel. Tenderness of the heel reproduced on dorsiflexion of toes is more typical for plantar fasciitis. 
❌ Neurogenic arthropathy :
Incorrect: Neurogenic arthropathy (charcot joint) presents with deformity and sensory deficits of the foot due to trauma, secondary to imapired proprioception and pain sensations. Therefore, pain is typically mild in these patients.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department after an injury to the left knee. The patient was running during a football game when he was suddenly tackled and struck in the lateral side of the left knee. The patient heard a “pop” and then felt pain at the medial aspect of his left knee. He was able to walk following the incident but noticed his left knee felt “wobbly”. On physical examination the left knee is swollen and there is medial joint line tenderness. The patient subsequently undergoes an MRI of the left knee, and the findings are shown below. Which of the following physical examination maneuvers is most likely to support this patient’s diagnosis?
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department following an injury that involved a valgus force to the lateral aspect of the knee. Knee MRI demonstrates evidence of injury to the medial collateral ligament. When a valgus stress test is used and valgus force is applied at the knee medial gapping and pain would indicate a positive test in the case of a medial collateral ligament injury.

Medial collateral ligament (MCL) and lateral collateral ligament (LCL) injuries are common injuries in athletes. These injuries often occur in isolation--without the involvement of concomitant ligamentous injuries. Injury to the medial collateral ligament most often is caused by a valgus force applied to the knee from forceful turning or twisting or from a direct blow to the lateral aspect of the knee. In contrast, lateral collateral ligament injuries occur due to a varus force to the knee from forceful twisting or turning or from a direct blow to the medial aspect of the knee.

Diagnosis of either injury is often clinical. In MCL injuries, patients will have increased gapping and pain at the medial knee when valgus force is applied. In LCL injuries, patients will have increased gapping and pain at the lateral aspect of the knee when varus force is applied. MRI is the definitive diagnosis and will demonstrate increased signal intensity at the ligaments with partial tears or visible full-thickness tears.  

Option Analysis

✅ Valgus stress test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Varus stress test:
Incorrect: Varus force applied at the knee joint would demonstrate increased gapping in the setting of a lateral collateral ligament injury. This patient's clinical presentation is more consistent with a medial collateral ligament injury.  
❌ Lachman test:
Incorrect: Lachman test is used to assess for anterior-cruciate ligament injury. It is not used to evaluate for medial collateral ligament injury. This patient’s medial knee pain and mechanism of injury are more consistent with a medial collateral ligament injury.  
❌ Thessaly test:
Incorrect: Thessaly test is used to assess for meniscus injury. However, the MRI does not show evidence of meniscal injury.  
❌ Posterior drawer test:
Incorrect: The posterior drawer test identifies injury to the posterior cruciate ligament which usually occurs from an anterior force applied to a bent knee, not a lateral blow as seen in this case. The posterior drawer test is not used to evaluate for medial collateral ligament injury which this patient likely has.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with emergency medical services after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The patient was the front-seat passenger of a vehicle that rear-ended another car while traveling at 45 miles per hour. The patient's primary survey is intact, and the secondary survey is notable for left knee swelling and ecchymoses. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the left knee demonstrates a large joint effusion and ecchymoses. A “soft” end-feel and increased posterior translation of the left tibia is noted when the examiner applies a posterior force anteriorly to the upper tibia. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of injury resulting in this patient's clinical condition?

choices.text: Force applied to the anterior aspect of a flexed knee
Valgus force applied to the knee
Varus force applied to the knee
Valgus force applied to the knee

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a high-speed motor vehicle collision with evidence of trauma to the left knee and a positive posterior drawer test. These findings are consistent with a posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury. The most common mechanism of injury in PCL injuries involves a posteriorly directed force applied to the anterior aspect of a flexed knee.

Of all the ligaments in the knee, the PCL is injured least often since it is the knee's largest and strongest intra-articular ligament. Most injuries to the PCL occur via high force trauma, such as when a passenger slams their knee on the dashboard in a motor vehicle crash. PCL injuries rarely occur in isolation and often involve concomitant injury to the other intra-articular ligaments of the knee. Clinically,  the patient will experience instability of the knee, pain, and will have a knee effusion and a positive posterior drawer test.

Definitive diagnostic testing involves magnetic resonance imaging. PCL tears are more commonly partial rather than complete. In the sagittal plane, partially torn PCLs often demonstrate a “stretched” appearance with thickening and intrasubstance signal changes.  

Option Analysis

✅ Force applied to the anterior aspect of a flexed knee:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Valgus force applied to the knee:
Incorrect: Medial collateral ligament tears are often a result of a valgus force applied to the knee, such as when a football player is tackled from the side. This patient’s physical exam indicates a posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) injury and cause is typically and posteriorly directed  force applied to the anterior aspect of a bent knee.  
❌ Varus force applied to the knee:
Incorrect: Lateral collateral ligament tears occur due to varus forces applied to the knee. This patient has a positive posterior drawer test which indicates PCL injury.  
❌ Twisting force at the knee:
Incorrect: Meniscal tears are often produced by a twisting mechanism applied to the knee, such as when an individual is turning rapidly or landing from a large jump. This patient had a dashboard injury and has a positive posterior drawer test indicating a PCL injury.  
❌ Valgus force applied to the knee:
Incorrect: When a knee injury involves a valgus force applied to the knee, medial meniscal injury can result, as can a triad injury involving the medial meniscus, the anterior cruciate ligament, and the medial collateral ligament.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the clinic to be evaluated for right knee pain. The patient was playing basketball three weeks ago when he suddenly pivoted while running and dribbling to the basket and felt pain in the right knee. Since then, he has experienced pain that worsens with running. In addition, he feels like his knee is “catching” and “giving out”. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination of the bilateral knees does not demonstrate effusions or deformities When the examiner grasps the patient's thigh and pulls the tibia forward with the knee at 20° of flexion, there is no anterior translation of the tibia or “soft” end-feel. When the examiner attempts to translate the lower leg posteriorly, there is no “soft” end-feel or excessive posterior translation.. There is tenderness to palpation over the medial right joint line. No pain is elicited when the examiner flexes the right knee to maximal flexion beyond 90° and then extends the knee with internal rotation of the tibia and a varus stress. When the examiner returns the knee to maximal flexion and extends the knee with external rotation of the tibia and a valgus stress  pain and clicking are noted. Radiograph of the knee shows no fracture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after sustaining an injury involving a twisting force applied to the knee. Physical examination demonstrates a positive McMurray test with external rotation of the right knee and valgus stress applied. These findings are consistent with a medial meniscus injury.

Meniscal injuries are a common injury in athletes. This injury often arises from a twisting force applied to the knee while the foot is planted. Patients experience varying degrees of pain following the injury, with some patients seeking care immediately while others seek care weeks to months after the inciting event. Patients often recall a sensation of the knee “popping,” “clicking,” and a feeling that the knee “gives way” with specific movements. Additionally, movements that involve twisting, such as pivoting while running, often exacerbate the pain.  

Clinically, patients may have joint line tenderness, inability to squat or kneel, loss of smooth passive knee motion, and joint effusion if presenting soon after the injury. In addition, patients may have a positive McMurray test. This test is performed when the examiner flexes the knee to maximal flexion beyond 90° and then extends the knee with internal rotation of the tibia and a varus stress, then returns the knee to maximal flexion and extends the knee with external rotation of the tibia and a valgus stress. Pain or catching/locking with internal rotation and varus stress indicates a lateral meniscal tear, whereas pain or catching/locking with external rotation and valgus stress as seen in this patient indicates a medial meniscus tear. An additional physical examination maneuver to test for meniscal tears is the Thessaly test. The patient stands on the affected leg with the knee flexed at 5° and then 20° while the patient actively rotates the knee and the whole body externally and internally using the knee as the pivot point. Joint line pain or discomfort or clicking indicates a positive test.  

Option Analysis

✅ Medial meniscus injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral meniscus injury:
Incorrect: A lateral meniscus injury would be suspected if the McMurray test reproduces pain or clicking with internal rotation of the right knee and varus stress not external rotation and valgus stress as seen in this patient.  
❌ Anterior cruciate ligament injury:
Incorrect: This patient has a negative Lachman test making it unlikely that he has an underlying anterior cruciate ligament injury. He has a positive McMurray test which indicates a meniscal injury.  
❌ Posterior cruciate ligament injury:
Incorrect: Posterior cruciate ligament injuries are an uncommon injury overall as it is the largest ligament of the knee. The posterior cruciate ligament is more commonly injured in the setting of high-speed motor vehicle collisions and this patient has a negative posterior drawer test making it unlikely.  
❌ Tibial plateau fracture:
Incorrect: This patient’s knee radiograph shows no evidence of a tibial plateau fracture.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is currently postoperative on day two following a cervical lymph node dissection. The patient reports feeling well but states his shoulder seems “droopy.” Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a laterally displaced scapula and weakness with shoulder abduction. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) provides motor function to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles of the neck and upper back. Injury to this nerve often manifests with pain and weakness about the shoulder. Specifically, patients have an asymmetric neckline, drooping shoulder, laterally displaced scapula, and weakness with overhead abduction of the shoulder.

The most common mechanism of injury involves iatrogenic injury via radical neck dissections, cervical lymph node biopsies, and posterior and lateral cervical triangle surgeries. Additional injury causes include blunt or penetrating trauma; however, these are significantly less common.  

Option Analysis

✅ Spinal accessory nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Superior laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Isolated superior laryngeal nerve injury produces vocal fatigue and subtle voice quality, pitch, and projection changes. This patient presents with evidence of trapezius dysfunction.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the vagus nerve may result in paralysis to both the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent branch of the laryngeal nerve. This can result in both sensory and motor deficits of the larynx.  
❌ Long thoracic nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the long thoracic nerve more commonly occurs following chest wall surgeries. Clinical manifestations include a “winged scapula” due to the serratus anterior muscle weakness.  
❌ Supraclavicular nerve:
Incorrect: The supraclavicular nerve is a superficial sensory nerve originating from the superficial cervical plexus's C3 and C4 nerve roots. This patient presents with evidence of motor deficits.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he slipped and fell from a 14-foot ladder onto his right lower extremity. Radiographs reveal a right-sided complete transverse fracture of the distal tibia and fibula diaphysis. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has a 25-pack-year smoking history. The patient is subsequently managed with external fixation and discharged home. The patient returns to the clinic seven months later for evaluation of persistent pain and a clicking sensation at the level of the fracture. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a visible deformity of the right lower extremity. Sensation is intact bilaterally. A current x-ray of the right lower extremity is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?  


Reproduced by Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of persistent pain at the fracture site and x-ray findings of callus formation around the fracture margins and anterior and internal angulation is suggestive of fracture nonunion.  Fracture nonunion manifests with x-ray findings that demonstrate persistent radiolucent lines at the fracture site, with or without callus formation. Complications of malunion included degenerative joint disease, persistent pain, as well as deformity.  

The tibia, particularly its distal third, is more prone to delayed union or nonunion due to lower blood supply and muscle coverage. In addition, compartment syndrome is a frequent concern in tibia fractures and can occur in crush injuries without fractures and in open fractures. The hallmark of compartment syndrome is severe pain out of proportion to the injury.  

Option Analysis

❌ Complex regional pain syndrome:
Incorrect: Complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) is a rare chronic pain complication of unknown cause following trauma. CRPS is characterized by pain out of proportion to the original injury with swelling, pain, and vasomotor disturbances as the hallmarks of this syndrome. X-ray often shows patchy demineralization of bone.  
✅ Fracture nonunion :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Common peroneal nerve compression:
Incorrect: The common peroneal nerve is susceptible to injury as it courses laterally around the neck of the fibula. Injury at this location presents with weakness of foot dorsiflexion and eversion as well as sensory loss over the dorsum of the foot and lateral shin and between first and second toes. This patient’s injury occured in the distal tibia/fibula.   
❌ Skin and soft tissue infection:
Incorrect: Skin and soft tissue infections usually present with erythema, swelling and pain, often associated with fever, leukocytosis, and elevated inflammatory markers. It would not explain this patient’s prominent callus formation surrounding the tibial non union.  
❌ Myositis ossificans:
Incorrect: Myositis ossificans occur when calcifications develop within muscle tissue. It can occur as a complication of fractures, especially supracondylar fractures of the humerus. It would not explain this patient’s prominent callus formation surrounding the tibial non union.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of right ankle pain. The patient was playing football when she was struck by an opposing player causing her ankle to evert. She immediately felt an intense, sharp pain about the ankle and heard a “snap.” The patient was unable to ambulate off the field. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling around the right ankle and tenderness over the medial malleolus. Sensory examination is within normal limits. Peripheral pulses are equal bilaterally. A right ankle x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of ankle pain following an eversion injury, in combination with radiographic evidence of a right distal fibula and medial malleolus fracture is consistent with a bimalleolar fracture (Pott’s fracture).  

Ankle fractures most often result from a twisting mechanism of injury to the ankle. Inversion injuries typically result in distraction (stretching) of the lateral ankle structures with compression of the medial structures. In contrast, eversion injuries result in medial distraction with lateral compression. The structures that are distracted during the injury tend to fracture or tear before the compressed structures.    

A Pott’s fracture is a bimalleolar fracture (injury to both the medial and the lateral malleolus) that results from a combined abduction external rotation from an eversion force. A Pott's fracture often occurs in combination with a dislocation of the ankle or other fractures of the foot, ankle, or lower leg.  

Another type of fracture, called a trimalleolar fracture, occurs when a bimalleolar fracture occurs in conjunction with a fracture of the posterior malleolus. They have a higher risk of complications than bimalleolar fractures and more result from high energy mechanisms of injury. Both bimalleolar and trimalleolar fractures are considered unstable and require operative fixation.  


Trimalleolar fracture 
Reproduced from Radiopedia 

Option Analysis

❌ Anterior talofibular ligament tear:
Incorrect: Ankle sprains can have a similar clinical presentation to that of an ankle fracture such as swelling and pain about the ankle. Plain radiographs in these patients are typically normal.   
❌ Fifth metatarsal fracture:
Incorrect: Pain, swelling, and tenderness over the lateral border of the forefoot is consistent with a fifth metatarsal fracture. This patient has medial malleolar tenderness and swelling.   
✅ Bimalleolar fracture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Acute compartment syndrome:
Incorrect: Compartment syndrome is an orthopedic emergency that results from increased pressure within an enclosed fascial space. Patients present with severe pain that worsens with passive stretching of the affected muscles, paresthesias, as well as sensory and motor deficits. This patient’s medial malleolar tenderness and x-ray findings is suggestive of a bimalleolar fracture.  
❌ Achilles tendon rupture:
Incorrect: The gastrocnemius and the soleus tendon combine to form the Achilles tendon. Its rupture can occur during strenuous physical activities that involve sudden pivots or rapid acceleration. Tenderness and ecchymosis of the Achilles tendon is noted in affected patients.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man comes to the emergency department to be evaluated for left shoulder pain after a fall. The patient was skiing when he was accidentally hit from the right side and fell on his left shoulder and outstretched left hand. The patient did not strike his head or lose consciousness. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a man supporting his left arm with his right hand. There is tenderness and swelling at the proximal humerus. An x-ray of the left shoulder is shown below. Axillary nerve injury is suspected. Which of the following actions will be impaired due to this nerve injury?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia:

choices.text: Abduction and adduction of the fingers

questions.solution:
This patient’s left arm x-ray is consistent with a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus, which is an injury pattern that occurs below the greater tubercle and lesser tubercle, and above the deltoid tuberosity.  

The surgical neck is fractured much more frequently than the anatomical neck of the humerus and commonly results from a fall on the outstretched hand. It is a fracture seen in older patients particularly those with osteoporosis. Symptoms include pain over the proximal shoulder that radiates the arm's length and swelling. The axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral artery are at the structures that are at most risk of injury with this fracture pattern.    

The axillary nerve carries fibers from the C5-C6 branch of the brachial plexus, where it courses deep to the axilla below the shoulder joint and the surgical neck of the posterior humerus. Patients with injury to this nerve present with loss of sensation over the lateral upper arm and weakness with shoulder abduction (due to denervation of the deltoid muscle). Damage to the posterior circumflex humeral artery can lead to avascular necrosis of the humeral head.  

Option Analysis

❌ Elbow, wrist, and finger extension:
Incorrect: Elbow, wrist, and finger extension are functions of the radial nerve (C5-T1), which can be injured with midshaft fractures of the humerus. This patient has a fracture of the neck of the humerus.  
❌ Abduction and adduction of the fingers :
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve is susceptible to injury in patients with fractures of the hook of hamate of the hand which can be seen in athletes. Ulnar nerve injury can cause inability to abduct the index and little fingers and inability to adduct the thumb. This patient’s presentation and radiograph are consistent with a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus.   
❌ Wrist flexion and thumb opposition:
Incorrect: Proximal median nerve injury can result from supracondylar fractures of the distal humerus at the elbow and can lead to the inability to flex the wrist and oppose the thumb. This patient has a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus.  
✅ Arm abduction at the shoulder :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Forearm flexion and supination :
Incorrect: Upper nerve trunk compression can injure the musculocutaneous nerve. Patients typically present with loss of arm abduction at the shoulder (>15 degrees) and loss of sensation over the lateral arm. Compression of the musculocutaneous nerve lower in the arm at the coracobrachialis muscle, can lead to weakness with forearm flexion and supination and sensory loss over the lateral forearm.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation following a fall and associated right arm pain. The patient was rock climbing when he lost grip and fell approximately 3 m (6.5 ft) onto boulders below. The patient landed on his right arm and heard a snapping sound upon impact. He did not strike his head or lose consciousness. Past medical history is noncontributory, and the patient does not take any medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates swelling and bruising of the right upper arm and inability to extend the right wrist and the fingers of the right hand, and sensory loss over the posterior forearm and dorsolateral hand. Nerve injury at which of the following locations is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with radial nerve injury, likely due to a midshaft fracture of the humerus.  

Midshaft humerus fractures in young patients commonly result from a direct blow or a bending force applied to the humerus. Older patients can experience this type of injury with a fall onto an outstretched hand. Patients typically present with severe pain in the mid-arm but may also have referred pain to the shoulder or elbow. Swelling and ecchymosis are often apparent shortly after the injury. The radial nerve and deep brachial artery are two structures that can be injured with this injury pattern.  

The radial nerve carries fibers from C5-T1 and serves as a terminal branch of the brachial plexus. It provides motor innervation to the forearm extensors at the elbow and most hand extensors at the wrist. Sensory innervation includes the posterior forearm and most of the back of the hand, except for the back of the little finger and the adjacent half of the ring finger (innervated by the ulnar nerve).Injury to the radial nerve results in weakness of wrist, finger, and thumb extension and elbow supination . A wrist drop can often be seen with this type of injury.  



Option Analysis

❌ Carpal tunnel :
Incorrect: Repetitive hand and wrist use can lead to compression of the median nerve at the carpal tunnel. This typically results in pain and paraesthesias of the first 3½ digits of the affected hand. This patient neurologic deficit is suggestive of radial nerve injury.   
✅ Mid-shaft of the humerus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical neck of the humerus:
Incorrect:  Fractures of the surgical neck of the humerus typically result from a fall on an outstretched hand. This fracture pattern is most likely to damage the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral artery rather than the radial nerve. Axillary nerve injury leads to loss of sensation and abduction at the shoulder.  
❌ Hook of hamate :
Incorrect: The ulnar nerve can be injured at the hook of hamate from a fracture there. The ulnar nerve enters the wrist via Guyon’s canal bordered by the hook of the hamate. Patients typically present with sensory loss over the medial 1½ digits, hypothenar eminence, and weakness with wrist flexion/adduction, finger adduction/abduction, and flexion of fourth/fifth digits.  
❌ Coracobrachialis muscle:
Incorrect: The coracobrachialis muscle is innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve. The nerve pierces the coracobrachialis muscle and can be injured by a compression injury of this muscle (e.g., from weight lifting). Injury to this nerve results in weakness with forearm flexion and supination and sensory loss over the lateral forearm.

questions.text: A 24-year old man presents to the emergency department after injuring his right knee during a pick-up basketball game. The patient was running and dribbling toward the basket when he suddenly changed direction and felt a “pop” in the knee. The patient subsequently had intense pain, significant swelling of his knee, and felt like his knee would “give out” on him when ambulating. Currently he is able to bear weight without pain but still feels unsteady when ambulating. Physical examination is notable for a small right knee effusion. There is full range of motion of the knee without locking or clicking. Which of the following physical examination maneuvers is most likely to aid in diagnosing this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an effusion, pain, and joint instability after a rapid deceleration mechanism of injury. Together, these findings are concerning for an anterior cruciate ligament tear, best confirmed on physical examination with the Lachman test.

The knee's anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) is the most anterior ligamentous component of the knee joint. It prevents the tibia from sliding out in front of the femur and provides rotational stability. The ACL is the most commonly injured ligament in the knee and typically occurs in sports during moments of rapid deceleration, direction changes, or pivoting on a lower extremity with the foot planted. Symptoms include the sensation of a “pop” or “tear” during the injury as well as significant effusion, pain, and sensation of joint instability immediately after the incident.

Two physical examination techniques with high sensitivity for detecting ACL tears are the Lachman test and the anterior drawer test. The Lachman test involves flexing the knee at 20°with the patient supine. At the same time, the examiner places one hand behind the tibia and the other hand grasps the patient's thigh and pulls the tibia forward. A positive test is indicated by anterior translational of the tibia or a “soft” end feel. The anterior drawer test involves the examiner grasping the proximal lower leg below the tibial plateau with the knee in 90°of flexion and attempting to translate the lower leg anteriorly with the patient's foot planted on the examination table. Definitive diagnosis of ACL tear is achieved with MRI. Signs of ACL tear on MRI include swelling, increased signal intensity, fiber discontinuity and abnormal ACL orientation. An empty notch sign which is a fluid signal at the site of femoral attachment at the intercondylar notch may be seen and it denotes avulsion at the femoral attachment.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lachman test:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ober test:
Incorrect: The Ober test is used to evaluate tension in the iliotibial band. This test would not help assess for an anterior cruciate ligament injury which is present in this case..  
❌ McMurray test:
Incorrect: The McMurray test is used to detect a meniscal injury, which is less likely given this patient’s decreased effusion size and the presence of full range of motion of the knee without locking or clicking..  
❌ Thessaly test:
Incorrect: The Thessaly test, like the McMurray test, detects meniscal injuries. A meniscal tear is less likely in this patient, given that the swelling happened immediately and is subsequently subsiding and he has full range of motion of the knee without locking or clicking.  
❌ Posterior drawer test:
Incorrect: The posterior drawer test detects excessive posterior translation or a “soft” endpoint of the proximal tibia when the posterior cruciate ligament is injured. Posterior cruciate ligament injury commonly occurs with a direct blow to the front of the knee such as when a bent knee hits the dashboard in a motor vehicle collision. Based on this patient’s mechanism of injury, an anterior cruciate ligament injury is more likely.
